{{DEFAULTSORT:Kelvin-Helmholtz Mechanism}} [[Category:Astrophysics]] [[Category:Stellar evolution]] [[Category:Effects of gravitation]] [[Category:Hermann von Helmholtz|Mechanism]] [[Category:William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin]]

'''letsrecycle.com''' is a UK-based website for reporting news and information related to the [[waste management]] and [[recycling]] industries.<ref>[http://www.iwm.co.uk/intranet/itm10794.htm letsrecycle.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928181039/http://www.iwm.co.uk/intranet/itm10794.htm |date=2007-09-28 }}, www.ciwm.co.uk, [[Chartered Institute of Wastes Management]], Retrieved 30.11.06</ref> The website produces daily news and information and is one of the key providers of news in the UK [[waste]] industry. It carries a range of pricing information for recyclable materials including waste paper, scrap metal, plastics, glass, organics and wood. It is the UK's only independent dedicated website for businesses, local authorities and community groups involved in recycling and waste management.<ref>[http://www.letsrecycle.com/info/about/index.jsp About letsrecycle.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061212101705/http://www.letsrecycle.com/info/about/index.jsp |date=2006-12-12 }}, www.letsrecycle.com, Retrieved 30.11.06</ref> The site also has a discussion board, "clubrecycle", where waste managers and stakeholders can discuss industry developments.
The company is involved in a number of other dynamics in the waste industry, including the annual LARAC conference for local authorities and the Awards for Excellence in Recycling and Waste Management. It is widely cited as a place of reference by industry organisations, government and local authorities<ref>[http://www.lichfielddc.gov.uk/site/scripts/documents_info.php?documentID=199&pageNumber=11 Awards for Excellence in Recycling and Waste Management - 'Recycling Champion of the Year'], www.lichfielddc.gov.uk, Lichfield District Council, Retrieved 30.11.06</ref><ref>[http://www.nottinghamshire.gov.uk/home/environment/recycling/links.htm Useful links], www.nottinghamshire.gov.uk, Nottinghamshire County Council, Retrieved 30.11.06</ref><ref>[http://www.sustainabilityfirst.org.uk/docs/wasterepdfversion.pdf Thinking Outside the Bin- Sustainability First] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021195830/http://www.sustainabilityfirst.org.uk/docs/wasterepdfversion.pdf |date=2007-10-21 }}, www.sustainabilityfirst.org.uk, Retrieved 30.11.06</ref><ref>[[NetRegs]]</ref><ref>[http://ims.npt.gov.uk/imsapps/waste/waste_links_i_to_q.aspx Waste links] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060629012218/http://ims.npt.gov.uk/imsapps/waste/waste_links_i_to_q.aspx |date=2006-06-29 }}, www.npt.gov.uk, Neath Port Talbot Council, Retrieved 30.11.06</ref><ref>[http://www.est.org.uk/myhome/newscentre/dailynews/index.cfm?mode=archive&Start=721 Daily News], www.est.org.uk, Energy Savings Trust, Retrieved 30.11.06</ref>
The editorial team consists of Steve Eminton, Will Date, Beth Slow and Joshua Doherty with design by Chloe Doel.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.letsrecycle.com/about/team.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809060610/http://www.letsrecycle.com/about/team.html |archivedate=2009-08-09 |df= }}</ref> In 2010, letsrecycle.com added a YouTube account <ref>https://www.youtube.com/letsrecyclecom</ref> and Twitter account @letsrecycle <ref>https://twitter.com/letsrecycle</ref> letsrecycle.com's sister website is AirQualityNews.com, the leading UK provider of news and information about air quality and air pollution. The websites are published by the Environment Media Group Ltd.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.letsrecycle.com/ Letsrecycle]
[[Category:Waste management companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Recycling industry]] [[Category:British news websites]]

|- |Annosus root disease ||''[[Heterobasidion annosum]]''
''[[Spiniger meineckellum]]'' [anamorph] |- |Armillaria root disease ||''[[Armillaria solidipes]]''
''[[Armillaria]]'' spp. |- |Black stain root disease ||''[[Leptographium wageneri var. pseudotsugae]]'' |- |Blue stain fungus ||''[[Grosmannia clavigera]]'' |- |Bleeding sap rot ||''[[Stereum sanguinolentum]]'' |- |Brown crumbly rot ||''[[Fomitopsis pinicola]]'' |- |Brown cubical rot ||''[[Laetiporus sulphureus]]'' |- |Brown trunk rot ||''[[Fomitopsis officinalis]]'' |- |Charcoal root disease ||''[[Macrophomina phaseolina]]'' |- |Conifer – aspen rust ||''[[Melampsora medusae]]'' |- |Conifer – cottonwood rust ||''[[Melampsora occidentalis]]'' |- |Cytospora canker ||''[[Leucostoma kunzei]]''
''[[Cytospora kunzei]]'' [anamorph]
''[[Valsa abietis]]''

''[[Phytophthora]]'' spp.
''[[Pythium]]'' spp.
''[[Rhizoctonia]]'' spp. |- |Dermea canker ||''[[Dermea pseudotsugae]]'' |- |Dime canker ||''[[Durandiella pseudotsugae]]'' |- |Fusarium hypocotyl rot ||''[[Fusarium oxysporum]]'' |- |Gray-brown sap rot ||''[[Cryptoporus volvatus]]'' |- |Gray mold ||''[[Botrytis cinerea]]''
''[[Botryotinia fuckelinana]]'' [teleomorph] |- |Laminated root rot ||''[[Phellinus weirii]]'' |- |Phoma seedling blight ||''[[Phoma eupyrena]]'' |- |Phomopsis canker ||''[[Diaporthe lokoyae]]''
''[[Phomopsis lokoyae]]'' [anamorph] |- |Phytophthora root rot ||''[[Phytophthora]]'' spp. |- |Pitted sap rot ||''[[Trichaptum abietinum]]'' |- |Red-brown butt rot ||''[[Phaeolus schweinitzii]]'' |- |Red ring rot ||''[[Phellinus pini]]'' |- |Rhabdocline needle cast ||''[[Rhabdocline pseudotsugae]]''
''[[Rhabdocline weirii]]'' |- |Rhizina root disease ||''[[Rhizina undulata]]'' |- |Rose fomes rot ||''[[Fomitopsis cajanderi]]'' |- |Rust-red stringy white rot ||''[[Echinodontium tinctorium]]'' |- |Sclerophoma dieback ||''[[Sydowia polyspora]]''
''[[Sclerophoma pythiophila]]'' [anamorph] = ''[[Sclerophoma semenospora]]'' [anamorph] |- |Snow blight ||''[[Phacidium abietis]]'' |- |Snow/needle blight ||''[[Phacidium infestans]]'' |- |Sparrasis root rot ||''[[Sparrasis crispa]]'' |- |Stringy butt rot ||''[[Perenniporia subacida]]'' |- |Swiss needle cast ||''[[Phaeocryptopus gaeumannii]]'' |- |Tomentosus root rot ||''[[Inonotus tomentosus]]'' |- |Upper stem canker ||''[[Phoma eupyrena]]''
''[[Fusarium avenaceum]]''
''[[Fusarium sambucinum]]'' |- |White stringy rot ||''[[Resinicium bicolor]]'' |} == References == *[http://www.apsnet.org/publications/commonnames/Pages/Douglas-fir.aspx Common Names of Diseases, The American Phytopathological Society] [[Category:Lists of plant diseases |Douglas-fir]] [[Category:Conifer pathogens and diseases]] [[Category:Pseudotsuga]]

page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on maples

revision.comment: Lower case for species common names as described at [[MOS:LIFE]] - also some copy editing using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''[[Maple]]s''', ''Acer'' species, are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] species. These include:
==[[Phagy|Monophagous]]== Species which feed exclusively on ''Acer'' * [[Gelechiidae]] ** ''[[Chionodes negundella]]'' - feeds on [[Manitoba maple]] (''Acer negundo'')
==[[Phagy|Polyphagous]]== Species which feed on ''Acer'' and other plants
*''[[Bucculatricidae]]'' ** ''[[Bucculatrix demaryella]]'' ** ''[[Bucculatrix thoracella]]'' * [[Coleophoridae]] ** ''[[Coleophora alniella]]'' - recorded on [[red maple]] (''Acer rubrum'') * [[Geometridae]] ** [[Engrailed (moth)|Engrailed]] (''Ectropis crepuscularia'') ** [[Feathered thorn]] (''Colotois pennaria'') ** [[Mottled pug]] (''Eupithecia exiguata'') - recorded on [[sycamore maple]] (''Acer pseudoplatanus'') ** [[Mottled umber]] (''Erannis defoliaria'') ** [[November moth]] (''Epirrita dilutata'') ** [[Pale November moth]] (''Epirrita christyi'') ** [[Winter moth]] (''Operophtera brumata'') * [[Lymantriidae]] ** [[Brown-tail]] (''Euproctis chrysorrhoea'') * [[Noctuidae]] ** [[Dun-bar]] (''Cosmia trapezina'') ** [[Grey dagger]] (''Acronicta psi'') - recorded on [[Norway maple]] (''Acer platanoides'') ** [[Miller (moth)|Miller]] (''Acronicta leporina'') - recorded on Norway maple (''Acer platanoides'') ** [[Satellite (moth)|Satellite]] (''Eupsilia transversa'') ** [[Setaceous Hebrew character]] (''Xestia c-nigrum'') ** [[Svensson's copper underwing]] (''Amphipyra berbera'') ** [[Sycamore (moth)|Sycamore]] (''Acronicta aceris'') * [[Notodontidae]] ** [[Buff-tip]] (''Phalera bucephala'') - recorded on Norway maple (''Acer platanoides'') ** [[Coxcomb prominent]] (''Ptilodon capucina'') - recorded on Norway maple (''Acer platanoides'') ** [[Rough prominent]] (''Nadata gibbosa'') * [[Saturniidae]] ** [[Io moth]] (''Automeris io'') - recorded on red maple (''Acer rubrum'') ** [[Rosy maple moth]] (''Dryocampa rubicunda'') ** [[Imperial moth]] (''Eacles imperialis'') ** [[Polyphemus moth]] (''Antheraea polyphemus'') ** [[Promethea silkmoth]] (''Callosamia promethea'')
==External links== *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Acer&sort=Taxon "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Acer''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 8 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Maples]] [[Category:Acer|+Lepidoptera]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Hatteras Island damage by Hurricane Isabel.jpg|right|thumb|300px|New inlet created by Hurricane Isabel|alt=Aerial view of a barrier island, temporarily separated into two segments.]] [[North Carolina]] is a U.S. state located on the [[Atlantic Seaboard]] in the southeastern United States. [[Tropical cyclones]]—[[storm]]s characterized by a large [[low pressure system|low-pressure]] center and numerous [[thunderstorms]] that produce strong winds and heavy rain—regularly affect the state. According to statistical hurricane research between 1886 and 1996 by the North Carolina State Climatology Office, a tropical cyclone makes [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] along the coastline about once every four years. An estimated 17.5% of all [[North Atlantic hurricane|North Atlantic tropical cyclones]] have affected the state.<ref name="ncclimate">{{cite web|author=State Climate Office of North Carolina|year=2006|title=Hurricanes in North Carolina|accessdate=2008-04-03|url=http://www.nc-climate.ncsu.edu/print/8|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330154058/http://www.nc-climate.ncsu.edu/print/8|archivedate=2010-03-30|df=}}</ref>
This list documents 52 tropical cyclones known to have affected the state between 2000 and the present. The most active month is September, with 20 total storms, while November is the least active month with two storms. While the most intense storm was [[Hurricane Isabel]] in 2003, [[Hurricane Florence]] in 2018 was the most destructive and caused the most fatalities. The first storm to impact the state during the period was [[Hurricane Florence (2000)|Hurricane Florence]] in September 2000, and the most recent was [[Hurricane Michael]] in October 2018; with [[Hurricane Florence]] in September 2018 before. In terms of windspeeds, [[Hurricane Isabel]] was the strongest storm to affect the state, producing [[maximum sustained winds]] equivalent to Category 2 status on the [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane scale]].<ref name="chron">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division |year=2008 |title=Chronological List of All Hurricanes which Affected the Continental United States: 1851–2007 |publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration |accessdate=2010-04-12 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/ushurrlist18512007.txt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921102626/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/ushurrlist18512007.txt |archivedate=2008-09-21 |df= }}</ref>
==2000–2002==
* September 12, 2000 – Rip currents from [[Hurricane Florence (2000)|Hurricane Florence]] kill three people due to drowning.<ref name="flo00">{{cite web|author=James Franklin |year=2000 |title=Hurricane Florence Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-01 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000florence.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101004183435/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000florence.html |archivedate=2010-10-04 |df= }}</ref> * September 19, 2000 – The extratropical remnants of [[Hurricane Gordon (2000)|Hurricane Gordon]] track through the state, dropping light to moderate rainfall.{{Tropical Cyclone Rainfall in the Southeastern United States}} * September 23, 2000 – [[Tropical Storm Helene (2000)|Tropical Depression Helene]] re-intensifies into a tropical storm over the northeastern portion of the state, producing moderate rainfall across much of the state which peaks at 8.31 inches (211 mm) in [[Longwood, North Carolina|Longwood]].<ref name="WPCSE"/> * June 13, 2001 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Allison]] enter the state as a [[subtropical cyclone|subtropical depression]] and drop over 10 inches (250 mm) of rainfall in the northeastern portion of the state; the rainfall results in nine indirect deaths due to traffic accidents on slick roads.<ref name="all01">{{cite web|author=Stacy Stewart |year=2001 |title=Tropical Storm Allison Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-01 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001allison.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916074527/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001allison.html |archivedate=2008-09-16 |df= }}</ref> * August 8, 2001 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Barry (2001)|Tropical Storm Barry]] drop light rainfall in the state's mountainous region.<ref name="bar01rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Barry|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/barry2001.html}}</ref> * July 14, 2002 – [[Tropical Storm Arthur (2002)|Tropical Storm Arthur]] forms just offshore and drops light rainfall near the coast.<ref name="WPCSE"/> * September 10, 2002 – [[Hurricane Gustav (2002)|Tropical Storm Gustav]] strikes the Outer Banks with a 5-foot (1.5 m) storm surge and hurricane force wind gusts, causing minor damage.<ref name="ga02">{{cite web|author=Jack Beven|year=2003|title=Hurricane Gustav Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-12-01|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002gustav.shtml}}</ref> * September 15, 2002 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Hanna (2002)|Tropical Storm Hanna]] drop moderate rainfall across much of the state, causing some flooding in Wilmington.<ref name="he02ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2002|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Hanna|accessdate=2007-12-01|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~470354}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * September 27, 2002 – The large wind field of what was once [[Hurricane Isidore]] downs trees and power lines across the western portion of the state, which blocks numerous roads.<ref name="is02ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2002|title=Event Report for Tropical Depression Isidore|accessdate=2007-12-01|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~470365}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * October 11, 2002 – [[Hurricane Kyle (2002)|Tropical Storm Kyle]] makes landfall near [[Long Beach, North Carolina|Long Beach]], spawning an [[Fujita Scale|F2]] tornado in [[Pantego, North Carolina|Pantego]] and a few weaker tornadoes. The passage of the storm results in about a dozen damaged or destroyed houses, but no deaths or injuries in the state.<ref name="ky02">{{cite web|author=Stacy Stewart |year=2002 |title=Hurricane Kyle Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-01 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002kyle.shtml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111022014734/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002kyle.shtml |archivedate=2011-10-22 |df= }}</ref>
==2003–2004== * July 2, 2003 – [[Tropical Storm Bill (2003)|Tropical Depression Bill]] crosses the extreme western portion of the state. The storm drops locally heavy rainfall peaking at 9.7 inches (246 mm) in [[Transylvania County, North Carolina|Transylvania County]], with one fatality reported due to drowning.<ref name="bi03">{{cite web|author=Lixion Avila |year=2003 |title=Tropical Storm Bill Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-01 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003bill.shtml? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005072912/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003bill.shtml |archivedate=2008-10-05 |df= }}</ref> * July 26, 2003 – [[Tropical Depression Seven (2003)|Tropical Depression Seven]] hits Georgia, dropping light rainfall in southern North Carolina.<ref name="0703rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Depression Seven (2003)|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/td72003.html}}</ref> * September 2003 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Grace (2003)|Tropical Storm Grace]] produce light rainfall across much of the state.<ref name="gra03rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Grace|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/grace2003.html}}</ref> * September 4, 2003 – Rip currents from [[Hurricane Fabian]] cause one drowning death near [[Cape Hatteras]].<ref name="fa03">{{cite web|author=Richard Pasch|year=2003|title=Hurricane Fabian Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-12-01|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003fabian.shtml|display-authors=etal}}</ref> * September 12, 2003 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Henri (2003)|Tropical Storm Henri]] move across the eastern portion of the state, dropping light rainfall.<ref name="WPCSE"/> * September 18, 2003 – [[Effects of Hurricane Isabel in North Carolina|Hurricane Isabel]] makes landfall at [[Drum Inlet]] with winds of 105 mph (165 km/h) and causes three deaths in the state, one of which directly.<ref name="is03">{{cite web|author=Jack Beven & Hugh Cobb |year=2003 |title=Hurricane Isabel Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-02 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003isabel.shtml? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114014935/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003isabel.shtml |archivedate=2013-11-14 |df= }}</ref> Damage in the state totals $450 million, most of which in [[Dare County, North Carolina|Dare County]] where some homes are washed away.<ref name="is03ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2003|title=Hurricane Isabel Event Report|accessdate=2007-12-02|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~508872}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The storm surge produces a 2,000-foot (600 m) wide [[Isabel Inlet|inlet]] on [[Hatteras Island]], isolating [[Hatteras, North Carolina|Hatteras]] by road for two months.<ref name="outban">{{cite web|author=Fred Hurteau |year=2003 |title=The Dynamic Landscape of the Outer Banks |publisher=Outer Banks Guidebook |accessdate=2006-12-05 |url=http://www.outerbanksguidebook.com/dynamic.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928230129/http://www.outerbanksguidebook.com/dynamic.htm |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }}</ref> [[Image:Ivan NC Tornado Damage.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Tornado damage from Hurricane Ivan|alt=A partially destroyed house, with most of its roof and attic gone, is surrounded by scattered debris.]] * August 3, 2004 – [[Hurricane Alex (2004)|Hurricane Alex]] brushes the Outer Banks, producing strong waves and moderate storm surge flooding; one person is killed from the surf, and hundreds of vehicles and homes are flooded.<ref name="al04">{{cite web|author=James Franklin |year=2004 |title=Hurricane Alex Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-02 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004alex.shtml? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214032108/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004alex.shtml |archivedate=2007-12-14 |df= }}</ref> * August 13, 2004 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Bonnie (2004)|Tropical Storm Bonnie]] spawn an [[Fujita scale|F2]] tornado near [[Rocky Point, North Carolina|Rocky Point]], killing three people; the tornado also destroys 17 houses and severely damages 27 buildings.<ref name="bo04ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|title=Tropical Storm Bonnie Event Report|accessdate=2007-12-02|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~548385}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * August 14, 2004 – [[Hurricane Charley]] moves ashore just southwest of the North Carolina – South Carolina border, resulting in moderate winds and about $25 million in damage as it tracks across the eastern portion of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard Pasch|year=2004|title=Hurricane Charley Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004charley.shtml|display-authors=etal}}</ref> * August 30, 2004 – [[Hurricane Gaston (2004)|Tropical Depression Gaston]] traverses the state, bringing moderate precipitation which causes some flooding.<ref name="ga04ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|year=2004|title=Event Report for Hurricane Gaston|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~548423}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *September 8, 2004 – Former [[Hurricane Frances]] crosses the western portion of the state, dropping very heavy rainfall peaking at 23.6 inches (599 mm) on [[Mount Mitchell (North Carolina)|Mount Mitchell]].<ref name="WPCSE"/> The rainfall causes widespread flooding, with many creeks and rivers surpassing flood stage; hundreds of homes and businesses are damaged or destroyed.<ref name="fl04ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|year=2004|title=Event Report for Hurricane Frances|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~548461}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * September 17, 2004 – Former [[Hurricane Ivan]] tracks along the border between North Carolina and Tennessee, dropping heavy rainfall that peaks at 17.0 inches (432 mm) in [[Cruso, North Carolina|Cruso]], as well as producing 4 tornadoes in the state. The hurricane kills eight people in the state,<ref name="iv04">{{cite web|author=Stacy Stewart |year=2004 |title=Hurricane Ivan Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-02 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004ivan.shtml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060414003850/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004ivan.shtml |archivedate=2006-04-14 |df= }}</ref> and causes severe flooding just nine days after the previous cyclone tracked through the area; the flooding damages or destroy hundreds of buildings, and washes away several bridges.<ref name="iv04ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|year=2004|title=Event Report for Hurricane Ivan|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~548501}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * September 25, 2004 – Heavy surf from [[Hurricane Jeanne]] kills a man to the east of [[Oak Island (North Carolina)|Oak Island]] after he is thrown overboard from his boat.<ref name="je04ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|year=2004|title=Event Report for Hurricane Jeanne|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~548539}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Three days later the storm's remnants cross the western portion of the state, causing the third flood in a month; the flood from Jeanne is less severe and shorter in duration than that from Ivan and Frances.<ref name="je04ncdc2">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|year=2004|title=Event Report for Hurricane Jeanne (2)|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~548546}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==2005–2007== [[Image:Hurricane Ophelia 14 sept 2005 1605Z.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Hurricane Ophelia just off North Carolina|alt=Satellite image of a tropical cyclone near the United States east coast. It presents a pronounced eye feature.]] * June 12, 2005 – [[Tropical Storm Arlene (2005)|Tropical Depression Arlene]] passes west of the state, producing locally heavy rainfall peaking at 9.84 inches (250 mm) in [[Transylvania County, North Carolina|Transylvania County]].<ref name="WPCSE"/> * July 7, 2005 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Cindy (2005)|Hurricane Cindy]] spawn eight tornadoes in the state, including one near [[Harmony, North Carolina|Harmony]] that damages or destroys over a dozen structures.<ref name="cin05">{{cite web|author=Stacy Stewart|year=2006|title=Hurricane Cindy Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL032005_Cindy}}|format=PDF}}</ref><ref name="cin05ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|year=2005|title=Event Report for Hurricane Cindy|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~588352|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012115316/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~588352|archivedate=2008-10-12|df=}}</ref> * July 11, 2005 – [[Hurricane Dennis|Tropical Depression Dennis]] passes through Tennessee, with its large circulation dropping moderate to heavy precipitation in western North Carolina.<ref name="WPCSE"/> * August 30, 2005 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Katrina]] produce moderate rainfall and gusty winds in the western portion of the state.<ref name="WPCSE"/><ref name="ka05ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|year=2005|title=Event Report for Hurricane Katrina|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~588569}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * September 14 – September 16, 2005 – [[Hurricane Ophelia (2005)|Hurricane Ophelia]] drifts just offshore of the Outer Banks, dropping heavy rainfall peaking at 17.5 inches (445 mm) and causing $70 million in damage.<ref name="op05">{{cite web|author=Jack Beven & Hugh Cobb|title=Hurricane Ophelia Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-02 |format=PDF|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL162005_Ophelia}}}}</ref> * October 7, 2005 – [[Tropical Storm Tammy (2005)|Tropical Storm Tammy]] drops light rainfall in the southern portion of the state,<ref name="WPCSE"/> and later combines with another disturbance to cause widespread flooding.<ref name="tancdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|year=2005|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Tammy|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~588585}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * October 23, 2005 – The outer rainbands of [[Hurricane Wilma]] drop over 3 inches (75 mm) of precipitation in the Outer Banks.<ref name="wil05rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Wilma|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-12-02|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/wilma2005.html}}</ref> [[Image:Alberto NC flooding - edit.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Flooding in North Carolina from Tropical Storm Alberto|alt=A road entirely submerged with murky flood waters.]] * June 14, 2006 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Alberto (2006)|Tropical Storm Alberto]] cross the state, producing heavy rainfall peaking at 7.16 inches (182 mm) in [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]];<ref name="WPCSE"/> the rain causes one indirect death when a boy runs into a flooded drainage system and drowns.<ref name="al06tcr">{{cite web|author=Lixion Avila & Daniel Brown|year=2006|title=Tropical Storm Alberto Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-04 |url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL012006_Alberto}}|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 1, 2006 – [[Hurricane Ernesto (2006)|Tropical Storm Ernesto]] makes landfall on [[Oak Island (North Carolina)|Oak Island]] and floods dozens of houses due to heavy rainfall; damage is estimated at over $20 million, primarily from crop damage.<ref name="er06ncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2006|title=Event Report for Hurricane Ernesto|accessdate=2007-12-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~628447}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * May 7, 2007 – The precursor to [[Subtropical Storm Andrea (2007)|Subtropical Storm Andrea]] produces rough waves along the state's coastline, causing moderate damage along the Outer Banks and killing four people in a boat offshore.<ref name="an07">{{cite web|author=Jamie Rhome|year=2007|title=Subtropical Storm Andrea Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-04 |url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL012007_Andrea}}|format=PDF|display-authors=etal}}</ref> * June 3, 2007 – The extratropical remnants of [[Tropical Storm Barry (2007)|Tropical Storm Barry]] crosses the eastern portion of the state and drops light rainfall.<ref name="WPCSE"/> * August 22, 2007 – Light rainfall occurs in association with the remnants of [[Tropical Storm Erin (2007)|Tropical Storm Erin]] passing through the area.<ref name="er07rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Erin|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-12-04|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/erin2007.html}}</ref> * September 9, 2007 – [[Tropical Storm Gabrielle (2007)|Tropical Storm Gabrielle]] moves ashore on the [[Cape Lookout National Seashore]], producing locally heavy rainfall but causing little damage.<ref name="ga07tcr">{{cite web|author=Daniel Brown|year=2007|title=Tropical Storm Gabrielle Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2007-12-04 |format=PDF|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL072007_Gabrielle}}}}</ref> * September 15, 2007 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Humberto (2007)|Hurricane Humberto]] drop light rainfall across much of the state before dissipating over the [[Appalachian Mountains]].<ref name="hu07rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Humberto|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center |accessdate=2007-12-04 |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/humberto2007.html}}</ref> * November 3, 2007 – Moderate winds from the extratropical remnants of [[Hurricane Noel (2007)|Hurricane Noel]] leave about 6,000 people without power in the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Anne Leake|year=2007|title=Outer Banks Get Wind, Little Rain From Storm |publisher=WRAL.com |accessdate=2007-11-04|url=http://www.wral.com/news/state/story/1998320/}}</ref>
==2008–present== [[File:Florence 2018-09-13 1550Z.jpg|thumb|right|Hurricane Florence approaching North Carolina]] * July 12, 2008 – Offshore [[Hurricane Bertha (2008)|Hurricane Bertha]] contributes to rip currents along the coast, leading to dozens of lifeguard rescues.<ref>{{cite web|title=Event Report for Hurricane Bertha|year=2008|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2009-11-16|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~731341}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * July 20, 2008 – [[Tropical Storm Cristobal (2008)|Tropical Storm Cristobal]] passes just offshore, dropping light rainfall and causing minor flooding.<ref>{{cite web|author=Estes Thompson|title=Tropical Storm Cristobal brushes NC coast|year=2008|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=2008-07-22|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gnYocoDdejbyeJxwRknvkqJ8hNIQD921TN8G6 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080801023510/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gnYocoDdejbyeJxwRknvkqJ8hNIQD921TN8G6 |archivedate = 2008-08-01}}</ref> * September 5, 2008 – [[Hurricane Hanna]] moves ashore near the South Carolina – North Carolina border, packing strong winds and torrential rains.<ref>{{cite web|title=Event Report for Hurricane Hanna|year=2008|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2009-12-22|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~740729}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Aside from minor structural damage, the storm's effects were generally minor.<ref>{{cite web|title=Event Report for Hurricane Hanna (2)|year=2008|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2009-12-22|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~740552}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * May 27, 2009 – The precursor to [[Tropical Depression One (2009)|Tropical Depression One]] passes just to the east of the state's coastline, triggering shower activity and increased wind.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Weather Underground|date=2008-05-27|accessdate=2009-05-28|title=History for Hatteras, NC: May 27, 2009 Weather|url=http://www.wunderground.com/history/airport/KHSE/2009/5/27/DailyHistory.html?req_city=NA&req_state=NA&req_statename=NA}}</ref> * August 22, 2009 – Category 4 [[Hurricane Bill (2009)|Hurricane Bill]] churns the Atlantic and generates long periods of rough surf and rip currents throughout the region. In North Carolina, numerous rescues are performed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Event Report for Hurricane Bill|year=2009|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2009-11-16|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~782346}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * August 28, 2009 – Rip currents from [[Tropical Storm Danny (2009)|Tropical Storm Danny]] result in the death of a 12-year-old boy.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jeff Hampton and Patrick Wilson|title=Coast Guard ends search for boy missing off Corolla|year=2009|publisher=''The Virginian-Pilot''|accessdate=2010-02-02|url=http://www.norfolk.com/2009/08/12yearold-missing-after-falling-bodyboard-corolla}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> * November 12, 2009 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Ida (2009)|Hurricane Ida]] contribute to the formation of a strong and damaging [[extratropical cyclone]] along the U.S. East Coast.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lixion A. Avila and John Cangialosi|title=Hurricane Ida Tropical Cyclone Report|year=2009|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2010-02-02|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL112009_Ida}}|format=PDF}}</ref> Heavy rainfall, up to {{convert|14.03|inch|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Manteo, North Carolina|Manteo]], occurs in portions of the state.<ref name="WPCSE"/> * August 7, 2010 – Rip currents from [[Tropical Storm Colin (2010)|Tropical Storm Colin]] kill a 51-year-old man off the coast of [[Ocracoke, North Carolina|Ocracoke]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff Writer |publisher=WVEC |date=August 9, 2010 |accessdate=August 9, 2010 |title=Maryland man drowns in North Carolina |url=http://www.wvec.com/news/local/Maryland-man-drowns-in-North-Carolina--100261959.html |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rrThPopn?url=http://www.wvec.com/news/local/Maryland-man-drowns-in-North-Carolina--100261959.html |archivedate=August 9, 2010 }}</ref> * September 3, 2010 – [[Hurricane Earl (2010)|Hurricane Earl]] passes just east of the Outer Banks, inundating portions of [[North Carolina Highway 12]] with storm surge and producing hurricane-force wind gusts that severely damaged six houses. Moderate crop damage was reported further inland, and monetary damage in the state reached $2.5 million (2010 USD).<ref>{{cite web|author=Cole |publisher=Newport/Morehead City, NC National Weather Service |date=2010-09-11 |title=Post Tropical Cyclone Report...Hurricane Earl...Updated |accessdate=2010-09-20 |url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/er/mhx/Text/EarlPSH.txt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5stLtjacG?url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/er/mhx/Text/EarlPSH.txt |archivedate=2010-09-20 |df= }}</ref> * September 19, 2010 – A surfer dies in strong waves from [[Hurricane Igor (2010)|Hurricane Igor]] in [[Surf City, North Carolina|Surf City]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Matt Tomsic|agency=Star News Online|date=2010-09-19|title=Surfer dies after being pulled from water at Surf City|accessdate=2010-09-20|url=http://www.starnewsonline.com/news/20100919/surfer-dies-after-being-pulled-from-water-at-surf-city}}</ref> * August 27, 2011 – [[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Hurricane Irene]] makes landfall in [[Cape Lookout (North Carolina)|Cape Lookout]] as a [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 1]] hurricane, causing seven total casualties as well as severe wind and flood damage.<ref>{{cite news|author=accuweather|publisher=accuweather|date=2011-08-28|title=Damage from Irene Assessed by North Carolina Governor|url=http://www.accuweather.com/blogs/news/story/54360/damage-from-irene-assessed-by.asp}}</ref> * October 26–30, 2012 – [[Hurricane Sandy]] passed by the state, dropping heavy rains and making storm surge. * July 3–4, 2014 – [[Hurricane Arthur]] hits eastern North Carolina, in particular the Outer Banks, with {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. * May 7, 2015 - [[Tropical Storm Ana (2015)|Tropical Storm Ana]] produced heavy rainfall and indirectly caused a fatality. * July 13, 2015 - The precursor to Tropical Storm Claudette produced moderate rainfall across the state. * May 30, 2016  - The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Bonnie (2016)|Tropical Storm Bonnie]] produce moderate rainfall across the central and eastern part of the state. * September 2, 2016  - [[Hurricane Hermine|Tropical Storm Hermine]] produces sustained tropical storm-force winds across the state. Over 200,000 households lose power, with damages in [[Dare County, North Carolina|Dare County]] totaling US$5.4 million. * September 15, 2016  - [[Tropical Storm Julia (2016)|Tropical Storm Julia]] passes to the south of the state and erratically drifts offshore. Parts of the state receive up to a foot of rain. A state of emergency is declared in 11 counties. * October 8, 2016 - [[Hurricane Matthew]] hugged the NC coast after making landfall in South Carolina, causing torrential rains, with as much as {{convert|15.65|inch|mm|abbr=on}} recorded at William O. Huske Locke 3. Wilmington set a new storm tide (water level measured relative to high tide) record at {{convert|3.53|ft|m|abbr=on}}, beating the previous one of {{convert|3.47|ft|m|abbr=on}} set during Hurricane Hazel on October 15, 1954. Matthew caused total devastation in Robeson County especially Lumberton. At least 28 people were killed, making Matthew the deadliest hurricane in North Carolina since Floyd killed 35 in 1999. * September 19, 2017 - Rough surf and swells from [[Hurricane Jose (2017)|Hurricane Jose]] flooded portions of the [[Outer Banks]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Molina|first=Camila|title=Rip currents from Hurricane Jose flood areas of OBX; parts of NC 12 closed|work=The News & Observer|location=Raleigh, NC|date=September 19, 2017|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/weather/article174092641.html|accessdate=September 20, 2017}}</ref> * Late September 2017  – [[Hurricane Maria]] brushes eastern North Carolina, producing some coastal floods, light rain and gusty winds. Damage is limited to the coastline; there is some beach erosion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Maria Brushes the North Carolina Coast|publisher=AccuWeather|url=https://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/maria-to-churn-high-seas-along-us-east-coast-may-approach-north-carolina/70002756|accessdate=Jan 24, 2018}}</ref> * Early July 2018  – [[Hurricane Chris (2018)|Tropical Storm Chris]] meanders to the southeast of the state, causing rough seas and rip currents, which were blamed for one fatality in Kill Devil Hills. *September 7–17, 2018  – [[Hurricane Florence]] made landfall less than a mile south of [[Wrightsville Beach, North Carolina]] with winds of {{convert|90|mph|km/h|abbr=on|round=5}}. The hurricane was first declared [[State of emergency|a threat to the state]] on Friday. Several people where rescued offshore due to rip currents affecting the area. * October 11, 2018 – [[Hurricane Michael|Tropical Storm Michael]] moves through the state, leaving several homes without power and killed 3 people after trees struck their cars.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Price |first1=Mark |title=Michael has now killed 3 in North Carolina. schools closed, 428,000 without power |url=https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/local/article219909120.html|publisher=Charlotte Observer |accessdate=October 12, 2018 |ref=https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/local/article219909120.html}}</ref>
==Monthly statistics== {{bar graph|float=center | title = Number of recorded storms affecting North Carolina | data_max = 30 | label_type = Month | data_type = Number of storms | label1 = January | data1 = | label2 = February | data2 = | label3 = March | data3 = | label4 = April | data4 = | label5 = May | data5 = 4 | label6 = June | data6 = 4 | label7 = July | data7 = 10 | label8 = August | data8 = 11 | label9 = September | data9 = 25 | label10 = October | data10 = 6 | label11 = November | data11 = 2 | label12 = December | data12 = }}
==Deadly storms== <center> {| class="wikitable sortable" align="center" |+Total deaths |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" !Name !! Year !! Number of deaths |- | [[Hurricane Florence (2000)|Florence (2000)]] || 2000 || 3 |- | [[Tropical Storm Allison|Allison]] || 2001 || 9 |- | [[Tropical Storm Bill (2003)|Bill]] || 2003 || 1 |- | [[Hurricane Fabian|Fabian]] || 2003 || 1 |- | [[Tropical Storm Bonnie (2004)|Bonnie]] || 2004 || 3 |- | [[Hurricane Jeanne|Jeanne]] || 2004 || 1 |- | [[Hurricane Ivan|Ivan]] || 2004 || 8 |- | [[Tropical Storm Alberto (2006)|Alberto]] || 2006 || 1 |- | [[Subtropical Storm Andrea (2007)|Andrea]] || 2007 || 4 |- | [[Tropical Storm Danny (2009)|Danny]] || 2009 || 1 |- | [[Tropical Storm Colin (2010)|Colin]] || 2010 || 1 |- | [[Hurricane Igor (2010)|Igor]] || 2010 || 1 |- | [[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Irene]] || 2011 || 7 |- | [[Hurricane Matthew|Matthew]] || 2016 || 28 |- | [[Hurricane Florence (2018)|Florence (2018)]] || 2018 || 39 |- | [[Hurricane Michael|Michael]] || 2018 || 3 |} </center>
==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} *[[List of North Carolina hurricanes]] *[[Geography of North Carolina]]

page.title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Blaenau Gwent

revision.text:
[[File:Blaenau Gwent UK location map.svg|thumb|200px|alt=Map of Blaenau Gwent within Wales|Map of Blaenau Gwent within Wales]] This is a list of the '''[[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) in the [[Blaenau Gwent]]''' [[Area of Search]] (AoS).<ref>{{cite web|title=County search of SSSIs|url=http://www.ccw.gov.uk/landscape--wildlife/protecting-our-landscape/special-landscapes--sites/sites-search-results.aspx?lang=en|publisher=[[Countryside Council for Wales]]|accessdate=21 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140305031552/http://www.ccw.gov.uk/landscape--wildlife/protecting-our-landscape/special-landscapes--sites/sites-search-results.aspx?lang=en|archivedate=5 March 2014|df=}}</ref>
==History== This Area of Search was mainly formed from parts of the previous AoS of [[Gwent (county)|Gwent]] as well as part of [[Brecknockshire|Brecknock]].
==Sites== * [[Brynmawr Sections]] * [[Cwm Clydach National Nature Reserve|Cwm Clydach]] * [[Cwm Merddog Woodlands]] * [[Mynydd Llangatwg]] ([[Mynydd Llangattock]])
==See also== * [[List of SSSIs by Area of Search]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{SSSI AOS lists}}
[[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Wales|Blaenau Gwent]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|Blaenau Gwent]]

page.title: List of endemic plants in the Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve

revision.comment: Fix unsupported parameter in Template:Columns-list or Template:Div col using [[WP:AutoEd|AutoEd]]
revision.text:
Of the 3,300 species of [[flowering plant]]s in the [[Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve]] in southern [[India]], 132 are [[endemism|endemic]]. The reserve encompasses portions of the [[Western Ghats]] and [[Nilgiri Hills]] in the states of [[Karnataka]], [[Kerala]], and [[Tamil Nadu]]. They are listed by [[Family (biology)|plant family]]. Plants with an asterisk* are listed in [[IUCN Red List|The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Plants with a dagger (†) are presumed extinct.Ranjit Daniels, R. J. (1996). ''The Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve: A Review of Conservation Status with Recommendations for a Wholistic Approach to Management''. Working Paper No. 16, 1996. UNESCO (South-South Cooperation Programme), Paris. [http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0011/001137/113753eo.pdf] {{columns-list|style=font-style:italic;| '''[[Acanthaceae]]''' * ''Andrographis lobelioides * ''A. stellulata * ''Leptacanthus amabilis * ''Mackenziea homotropa * ''M. violacea * ''Nilgirianthus papillosus * ''N. wighteanus * ''Phlebophyllum lanatum * ''Plecaulis sessilis * ''Rhinacanthus nasutus'' var. montanus * ''Thelepaepale bicolor '''[[Adoxaceae]]''' * ''Viburnum hebanthum '''[[Amaranthaceae]]''' * ''[[Achyranthes aspera]]'' f. var. rubrofusca '''[[Annonaceae]]''' * ''[[Goniothalamus wynaadensis]]*'' '''[[Apiaceae]]''' * ''Bunium nothum* '''[[Apocynaceae]]''' * ''Baeolepis nervosa '''[[Aquifoliaceae]]''' * ''[[Ilex gardneriana]]*† '''[[Araceae]]''' * ''Arisaema auriculatum * ''A. pulchrum * ''A. transluscens * ''A. tuberculatum * ''A. tylophorum '''[[Arecaceae]]''' * ''Calamus gamblei'' var sphaerocarpa '''[[Asclepiadaceae]]''' * ''Brachystelma maculatum * ''Caralluma nilagiriana '''[[Asteraceae]]''' * ''Anaphalis neelgeiryana * ''A. notoniana * ''Helichrysum wightii * ''Senecio kundaicus * ''S. lawsonii * ''S. lessigianus * ''S. polycephalus * ''Vemonia saligina'' var nilghirensis * ''Youngia nilgirriensis '''[[Balsaminaceae]]''' * ''Impatiens clavicornus'' * ''I. debilis * ''I. denisonii * ''I. laticornis * ''I. levengei * ''I. munronii * ''I. neo-barnesii * ''I. nilagirica * ''I. orchioides '''[[Celastraceae]]''' * ''Microtropis densiflora* '''[[Chrysobalanaceae]]''' * ''Atuna indica* '''[[Commelinaceae]]''' * ''Commelina tricolor '''[[Convolvulaceae]]''' * ''Argyreia coonoorensis '''[[Cyperaceae]]''' * ''Carex christii * ''C. pseudo-asperata * ''C. vicinalis * ''C. curvibracteatus * ''Fimbristylis latiniglumifera * ''F. latinucifera * ''F. rectifolia '''[[Eriocaulaceae]]''' * ''Eriocaulon christopheri * ''E. gamblei * ''E. pectinatum* * ''E. robustum* '''[[Euphorbiaceae]]''' * ''Dalechampia velutina * ''Glochidion sisparense * ''Mallotus subramanyamii * ''Reidia timbriata '''[[Fabaceae]]''' * ''[[Acacia hohenackeri]]'' * ''Crotalaria bidei * ''C. formosa * ''C. obtecta * ''Dalbergia gardneriana * ''Tephrosia wynaadensis '''[[Gentianaceae]]''' * ''Swertia lawii '''[[Labiatae]]''' * ''Anisochilus dysophylloides'' var purpureus * ''Leucas pubescens * ''L. rosmarinifolia * ''Pogostemon nilagiricus * ''P. paludosus * ''Teucrium wightii '''[[Lauraceae]]''' * ''[[Actinodaphne lanata]]*'' * ''[[Actinodaphne lawsonii]]*'' * ''[[Actinodaphne salicina]]*'' * ''[[Litsea stocksii]]'' f. var. ''glabrescens'' '''[[Loranthaceae]]''' * ''Dendrophthoe memecylifolia * ''D. neelgherrensis'' var clarkei * ''Loranthus recurvus '''[[Melastomataceae]]''' * ''Memecylon flavescens* * ''M. lawsonii * ''M. sisparense* * ''Sonerila versicolor'' var. axillaris * ''S. wynaadensis '''[[Myrtaceae]]''' * ''[[Eugenia argentea]] * ''[[Meteoromyrtus wynaadensis]]* * ''[[Syzygium malabaricum]] '''[[Orchidaceae]]''' * ''Aerides elatoir * ''Bulbophyllum acutiflorum * ''B. aureum * ''B. fusco-purpureum * ''B. kaitiense * ''B. nodosum * ''Coelogyne odoratissima'' var. angustifolia * ''Corymborkis veratifolia * ''Eria nana * ''E. polystachya * ''Habenaria cephalotes * ''H. denticulata * ''H. polyodon * ''Liparis biloba * ''Malaxis crenulata * ''Spiranthes sinensis'' var. wightiana * ''Thrixspermum muscaeflorum'' var nilagiricum * ''[[Vanda wightii]] '''[[Oxalidaceae]]''' * ''Biophytum polyphyllum '''[[Pittosporaceae]]''' * ''Pittosporum viridulatum* '''[[Poaceae]]''' * ''Andropogon longipes * ''A. polyptychus * ''Arudinella purpurea * ''A. setosa'' var ''nilgiriana'' * ''Brachiaria semiundulata * ''Eriochrysis rangacharii * ''Garnotia schmidii * ''Isachne deccanensis * ''I. nilagiricum * ''I. oreades * ''Ochlandra beddomei * ''O. setigera * ''Panicum fischeri * ''Poa gamblei '''[[Primulaceae]]''' * ''Embelia gardneriana * ''Maesa velutina* '''[[Ranunculaceae]]''' * ''Clematis theobromina'' '''[[Rubiaceae]]''' * ''Hedyotis hirsutissima * ''Lasianthus ciliatus * ''Oldenlandia hirsutissima * ''O. sisparensis * ''Ophiorrhiza brunois'' var ''Smilax wightii* '''[[Symplocaceae]]''' * ''Symplocos microphylla * ''S. pulchra '''[[Umbelliferae]]''' * ''Bupleurum plantaginifolium * ''Heracleum hookerianum '''[[Urticaceae]]''' * ''Pouzolzia This page contains a sortable table listing [[mountain]]s of [[Italy]]. All mountain heights and prominences on the list are from the largest-[[scale (map)|scale]] maps available.All mountain heights and prominences are from the following maps:
For France the 1:25,000 [http://www.geoportail.gouv.fr/accueil cartes topographiques] of the [[Institut Géographique National]]
For Switzerland the 1:25,000 [http://map.geo.admin.ch/ Swisstopo] maps.
For Austria [[Bundesamt für Eich- und Vermessungswesen|BEV]]'s [http://www.austrianmap.at Österreichische Karte 1:50.000] supplemented with the 1:25,000 [[Alpine Club map]]s where available.
For Italy the 1:25,000 [[Istituto Geografico Militare]] maps via the [http://www.pcn.minambiente.it Geoportale Nazionale] website.
Key cols were verified using the [[SRTM]] data based contour lines in the terrain view of [[Google maps]]. In the list, only the exact location of the culminating point of the mountain is considered. ==List== ===Alps=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center; background-color:#F9F9F9; font-size: 90%;" |- bgcolor="#dddddd" !Mountain !Height
(m) ![[Topographic prominence|Drop]] (m)
Numbers in italics are estimates because a precise height for the key col is lacking. !CoordinatesVerified and fine-tuned via [https://maps.google.com/maps google terrain and satellite maps]. !Range For the Eastern Alps the range names are according to the [[Alpine Club classification of the Eastern Alps]]. !Range[[SOIUSA]] codes, representing a proposal for a new classification system of the Alps. The codes usually but not always correspond to established ranges. Sorting on this tab puts the mountains in a geographic order, roughly from the southwest to the east. ![[Provinces of Italy|Province]] !FirstThe three main sources for first ascent data are:
For France and in general; [[W.A.B. Coolidge]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=df4OAAAAQAAJ The Alps in nature and history], Methuen & Co, London, 1908.
For Switzerland; [[Gottlieb Studer]], ''Über Eis und Schnee: Die höchsten Gipfel der Schweiz und die Geschichte ihrer Besteigung,'' Volumes 1-3, Schmid & Francke, Bern, 1896-1899.
For the Eastern Alps: ''Die Erschließung der Ostalpen'', Volumes 1-3, German and Austrian Alpine Club, Berlin, 1894.
Given are the years for the first recorded ascents. In many cases local people or surveyors made earlier ascents. In particular, chamois and ibex hunters are expected to have reached many summits. Years in italics indicate that it is known that an earlier ascent was made, for example by the presence of artifacts on top or the summit's prior use as a triangulation point.

page.title: List of nature centers in Oklahoma

revision.text:
<!-- Note: Please do not add websites for nature centers with existing Wikipedia articles. All websites should be listed on the main article. --> This is a list of [[nature center]]s and environmental education centers in the state of [[Oklahoma]].
To use the sortable tables: click on the icons at the top of each column to sort that column in alphabetical order; click again for reverse alphabetical order.
{{See also|List of nature centers in the United States}}
{| class="wikitable sortable" ! Name ! Location ! County ! Region ! Summary |- | [[Beavers Bend Resort Park]] || [[Broken Bow, Oklahoma|Broken Bow]] || [[McCurtain County, Oklahoma|McCurtain]] || Southeast || 3,482 acres, includes nature center and Forest Heritage Center, a forestry museum |- | [[Bernice State Park]] || [[Grove, Oklahoma|Grove]] || [[Delaware County, Oklahoma|Delaware]] || [[Green Country (Oklahoma)|Green Country]] || 88 acres, includes a nature center, wildlife feeding area and two wildlife watch towers |- | Byron State Fish Hatchery & Watchable Wildlife Area || [[Hulbert, Oklahoma|Hulbert]] || [[Alfalfa County, Oklahoma|Alfalfa]] || [[Northwestern Oklahoma]] || [http://www.wildlifedepartment.com/wildlifemgmt/byron.htm website], 40 acres, education programs, nature center open on a limited basis |- | [[Chickasaw National Recreation Area]] || [[Sulphur, Oklahoma|Sulphur]] || [[Murray County, Oklahoma|Murray]] || [[South Central Oklahoma|South Central]]|| 9,899 acres, Travertine Nature Center serves as the parks main educational center with natural history dioramas, live reptiles, amphibians and birds of prey, and an interactive learning area |- | [[Greenleaf State Park]] || [[Braggs, Oklahoma|Braggs]] || [[Muskogee County, Oklahoma|Muskogee]] || Green Country || 565 acres |- | Hackberry Flat Center || || [[Tillman County, Oklahoma|Tillman]] || [[Southwestern Oklahoma]] || [http://www.wildlifedepartment.com/education-old/hackberry_flat.htm website], education center for the 7,120-acre Hackberry Flat Wildlife Management Area, [https://www.facebook.com/Friends-of-Hackberry-Flat-209302429171557/ Friends of Hackberry Flat] |- | [[Kerr Arboretum and Botanical Area]] || [[Talihina, Oklahoma|Talihina]] || [[Le Flore County, Oklahoma|Le Flore]] || Southeast || 8,026 acres, located in [[Ouachita National Forest]] |- | [[Lake Eufaula State Park]] || [[Checotah, Oklahoma|Checotah]] ||[[McIntosh County, Oklahoma|McIntosh]] || Green Country || 2,853 acres, Deep Fork Nature Center |- | [[Lake Murray State Park]] || [[Ardmore, Oklahoma|Ardmore]] || [[Carter County, Oklahoma|Carter]] || South Central || 12,500 acres, Tucker Tower Nature Center |- | [[Lake Texoma State Park]] || [[Kingston, Oklahoma|Kingston]] || [[Marshall County, Oklahoma|Marshall]] || South Central || 1,882 acres, Two Rivers Nature Center |- | [[Lake Thunderbird State Park]] || [[Norman, Oklahoma|Norman]] || [[Cleveland County, Oklahoma|Cleveland]] || [[Oklahoma City metropolitan area|Oklahoma City Metro]] || 1,874 acres, Discovery Cove Nature Center in Clear Bay area |- | [[Lake Wister State Park]] || [[Wister, Oklahoma|Wister]] || [[Le Flore County, Oklahoma|Le Flore]] || Southeast || 3,428 acres |- | Martin Park Nature Center || [[Oklahoma City]] || [[Oklahoma County, Oklahoma|Oklahoma]] || Oklahoma City Metro || [https://www.okc.gov/departments/parks-recreation/martin-park-nature-center website], 144 acres, operated by the City |- | Oxley Nature Center || [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]] || [[Tulsa County, Oklahoma|Tulsa]] || Green Country || [http://www.oxleynaturecenter.org/ website], operated by the City in the 745-acre Mohawk Park |- | [[Quartz Mountain Nature Park]] || [[Lone Wolf, Oklahoma|Lone Wolf]] || [[Kiowa County, Oklahoma|Kiowa]] || Southwestern Oklahoma || 4,284 acres |- | [[Robbers Cave State Park]] || [[Wilburton, Oklahoma|Wilburton]] || [[Latimer County, Oklahoma|Latimer]] || Southeast || 8,246 acres |- | [[Salt Plains National Wildlife Refuge]] || [[Hulbert, Oklahoma|Hulbert]] || [[Alfalfa County, Oklahoma|Alfalfa]] || Northwestern Oklahoma || 32,080 acres, education programs, visitor center exhibits |- | [[Sequoyah State Park]] || [[Hulbert, Oklahoma|Hulbert]] || [[Cherokee County, Oklahoma|Cherokee]] || Green Country || 349 acres, Three Forks Nature Center |- | [[Tenkiller State Park]] || [[Vian, Oklahoma|Vian]] || [[Sequoyah County, Oklahoma|Sequoyah]] || Green Country || 1,190 acres, Driftwood Nature Center |- | [[Wichita Mountains Wildlife Refuge]] || [[Indiahoma, Oklahoma|Indiahoma]] || [[Comanche County, Oklahoma|Comanche]] || Southwestern Oklahoma || 59,020 acres, environmental education center at Quanah Parker Lake |- |}
==External links== * [https://maps.google.com/maps/ms?msid=216417627346176875400.0004e5a35b5b457164029&msa=0&ll=35.380093,-96.146851&spn=3.604988,8.453979 Map of nature centers and environmental education centers in Oklahoma]

page.title: List of retired Pacific typhoon names

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:FA RotBot|FA RotBot]])
revision.text:
[[File:Haiyan Nov 7 2013 1345Z.png|right|thumb|[[Typhoon Haiyan]] at peak intensity]] This is a list of all [[Pacific typhoon]]s that have had their names retired by the [[Japan Meteorological Agency]]. A total of 41 [[Tropical cyclone|typhoon]] names have been retired since the start of official [[List of previous tropical cyclone names|tropical cyclone naming]] in the western North [[Pacific Ocean]] in [[2000 Pacific typhoon season|2000]]. Tropical cyclone names are retired by the [[World Meteorological Organization]] (WMO) in a meeting in January or February. Those typhoons that have their names retired tend to be exceptionally destructive storms. Several names were removed or altered [[list of tropical cyclone names|naming list]] for various reasons other than retirement. Collectively, retired typhoons have caused over $99 billion in damage ({{#time:Y}} [[USD]]), as well as over 12,000 deaths. ==Background== {{main|Tropical cyclone naming|History of tropical cyclone naming|List of historic tropical cyclone names}} [[File:Aerial view of Tacloban after Typhoon Haiyan.jpg|right|thumb|[[Tacloban]] devastated by [[Typhoon Haiyan]]]] The practice of using names to identify tropical cyclones goes back several centuries, with systems named after places, saints or things they hit before the formal start of naming in the Western Pacific.{{cite journal|author=Smith, Ray|url=http://www.metsoc.org.nz/system/files/journals/10/1/1990_101_24-26_rsmith.pdf|journal=Weather and Climate|year=1990|publisher=The Meteorological Society of New Zealand|volume=10|title=What's in a Name?|issue=1|pages=24–26|accessdate=August 25, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129194207/http://www.metsoc.org.nz/system/files/journals/10/1/1990_101_24-26_rsmith.pdf|archive-date=November 29, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} These included the [[Kamikaze (typhoon)|Kamikaze]], [[1906 Hong Kong typhoon]], [[1922 Swatow typhoon]] and the [[1934 Muroto typhoon]].{{cite book|author=Landsea, Christopher W|author2=Dorst, Neal M|date=June 1, 2014|title=Tropical Cyclone Frequently Asked Question|chapter=Subject: Tropical Cyclone Names: B1) How are tropical cyclones named?|accessdate=August 25, 2014|deadurl=no|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/TCFAQ_B.txt|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Q9nmDAns?url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/TCFAQ_B.txt|archivedate=June 7, 2014|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Hurricane Research Division|df=}} The practice of retiring significant names was started during 1955 by the [[United States Weather Bureau]] in the Northern Atlantic basin, after hurricanes [[Hurricane Carol|Carol]], [[Hurricane Edna|Edna]], and [[Hurricane Hazel|Hazel]] struck the [[East Coast of the United States]] and caused a significant amount of damage in the previous year.{{cite web|title=They Called the Wind Mahina: The History of Naming Cyclones|author=Dorst, Neal|url=ftp://ftp.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/pub/dorst/Mahina.pptx|author2=Hurricane Research Division|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|page=Slides 8–72|date=October 23, 2012|format=PPTX}} Initially the names were only designed to be retired for ten years after which they might be reintroduced; however, it was decided at the 1969 Interdepartmental hurricane conference, that any significant hurricane in the future would have its name permanently retired.{{cite news|title=It's time (June) to match for Anna...|newspaper=The Daily Gleaner|date=June 1, 1969|author=Reuters|page=2|location=Kingston, Jamaica}}{{subscription required|via=The Newspaper Archive}} The first tropical cyclone name to be removed in the South Pacific was Rosie after it had impacted Vanuatu and New Caledonia during 1971. Several names have been removed from the Pacific naming lists for various other reasons than causing a significant amount of death/destruction, which include being pronounced in a very similar way to other names and political reasons.{{cite book|title=Regional Association IV: Hurricane Operational Plan 2013|date=May 30, 2013|author=RA IV Hurricane Committee|pages=98–99|url=http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/tcp/documents/OPERATIONALPLAN2013_en.pdf|publisher=World Meteorological Organization|chapter=Chapter 9: Tropical Cyclone Names|accessdate=June 6, 2014}} In 2000, the [[Japan Meteorological Agency]] (JMA) began naming tropical cyclones from a list of 140 names, submitted by 14 countries. Previously, the JMA labeled storms with numbers, but not names. The JMA has been the official warning agency of the western Pacific Ocean since 1981, though other organizations have also tracked typhoons. The [[Joint Typhoon Warning Center]] (JTWC) unofficially named tropical cyclones from [[1940–49 Pacific typhoon seasons#1947 Pacific typhoon season|1947]] to [[1999 Pacific typhoon season|1999]].{{cite web|publisher=[[Hong Kong Observatory]]|year=2007|title=Tropical Cyclones in 2006|accessdate=2008-03-04|url=http://www.weather.gov.hk/publica/tc/tc2006/english/section1.htm#1.3}} During this time period, there were several pre-determined [[list of previous tropical cyclone names|tropical cyclone lists]], in which many names were removed and replaced with others.{{cite web|author=Digital Typhoon |year=2006 |title=Typhoon List View |accessdate=2008-03-04 |url=http://agora.ex.nii.ac.jp/digital-typhoon/year/wnp/.html.en }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The [[Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration]] (PAGASA) names tropical cyclones using a separate list, which is adjusted periodically.{{cite web|author=Chris Landsea|year=2007|title=How are Tropical Cyclones Named?|publisher=Hurricane Research Division|accessdate=2008-03-05|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/TCFAQ_B.txt}} Several names were removed from the list. In 2002, the name ''Hanuman'' was replaced prior to being used, due to objection by the [[India Meteorological Department]] for reason of religion.{{cite web|author=Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific |year=2001 |title=Report of the Typhoon Committee on its Thirty-Fourth Session |publisher=World Meteorological Organization |accessdate=2008-03-04 |url=http://www.wmo.ch/pages/prog/www/TCP_vO/Typhoon-C/final-report-TC34-dec2001.doc |format=DOC }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Additionally, the name ''Kodo'' was replaced in 2002 without being used.{{cite web|author=Tropical Cyclone Programme|year=2008|title=Typhoon Committee Operational Manual — Meteorological Component|publisher=World Meteorological Organization|accessdate=2008-03-04|url=http://www.wmo.ch/pages/prog/www/tcp/documents/TCP-23EDITION2008.pdf|format=PDF}} The following year, Koni was replaced by Goni, after an apparent misspelling was made. In 2004, the names ''Yanyan'' and ''[[Typhoon Tingting|Tingting]]'' were removed at the request of the [[Hong Kong Observatory]].{{cite web|publisher=Hong Kong Observatory |year=2005 |title=Change of Tropical Cyclone Names : "Dolphin" and "Lionrock" to replace "Yanyan" and "Tingting" |accessdate=2008-03-04 |url=http://210.0.235.9/wxinfo/news/2005/pre1124e.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011115126/http://210.0.235.9/wxinfo/news/2005/pre1124e.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-10-11 }} A total of nine names on the list had their spellings changed. In February 2014, the name ''Sonamu'' was removed at the request from [[Malaysia]] due to causing unprecedented panic by the similar pronunciation to ''tsunami''.{{cite web|title=Retirement of Names from the List of Names of Tropical Cyclones for the Typhoon Committee Region|url=http://www.typhooncommittee.org/46th/Docs/item%2011%20Programme/11.3%20retired%20TC%20name.pdf|publisher=Typhoon Committee|accessdate=21 February 2014}} In February 2015 the name ''Jongdari'' was chosen as replacement for ''Sonamu''. In the 46th session of the Typhoon Committee, it was noted the name ''Vicente'' appears on both the tropical cyclone name lists for the Western North Pacific and Eastern North Pacific. In response to this duplication the name ''Lan'' was chosen as replacement for ''Vicente'' on the Western North Pacific name list to avoid potential confusion. ==20th century== [[File:Typhoon Mireille 22 sept 1991 2236Z.jpg|thumb|Typhoon Mireille near peak intensity on September 22, 1991]] Between 1947 and 2000, eleven names of significant tropical cyclones were retired from the list of names used by the United States [[Joint Typhoon Warning Center]].{{cite journal|author=Zhou, Xiao|author2=Lei, Xiaotu|year=2012|title=Summary of retired typhoons within the Western North Pacific Ocean|volume=1|issue=1|publisher=The Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific/World Meteorological Organization's Typhoon Committee|issn=2225-6032|journal=Tropical Cyclone Research and Review|pages=23–32|accessdate=December 21, 2014|doi=10.6057/2012TCRR01.03|url=http://tcrr.typhoon.gov.cn/EN/article/downloadArticleFile.do?attachType=PDF&id=7}} During this time other names were removed from the naming lists, including in 1979 when the lists of names used were revised to include both male and female names.{{cite report |author1=Naval Oceanography Command Center |author2=Joint Typhoon Warning Center |archivedate=November 14, 2014 |title=Annual Typhoon Report: 1979 |page=10 |url=http://www.usno.navy.mil/NOOC/nmfc-ph/RSS/jtwc/atcr/1979atcr.pdf |deadurl=no |chapter=Chapter III: Summary of Tropical Cyclones |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6U4xLZtah?url=http://www.usno.navy.mil/NOOC/nmfc-ph/RSS/jtwc/atcr/1979atcr.pdf |df= }} Tropical Storm Lucille was the first name to be retired for its impacts, while Ophelia was retired because of its long {{convert|5000|mi|km|disp=flip|round=5|abbr=on}} track. {{Pacific areas affected (Top)}} |- | [[Tropical Storm >{{ntsp|{{#expr:3600000+660000000+4200000000+730000000+340000000+4800000000+14000000+23700000+2440000000+2330000000+535000000+971000000+478000000+4400000000+2500000000+750000000+400000000+6200000000+1090000000+617000000}}||$}} || >{{nts|{{#expr:5+54+238+1+64+117+12+169+29+32+149+268+859+458+312+1500+789+710+500}}}} || |} ==2010s== [[File:Fitow Oct 5 2013 0210Z.jpg|thumb|Typhoon Fitow at peak intensity on October 5, 2013]] So far during the current decade twenty names have had their names retired by the Typhoon Committee. Collectively, these systems killed at least {{#expr:105+2546+13+1901+2+97+12+8052+222+59+29+62+51+47+37+19+13+24+83+266}} people and caused at least {{ntsp|{{#expr:1004710000+97800000+324238000+1040000000+3562430000+10400000000+13807460000+8077000000+3839460000+4251300000+308700000+148880000+4802130000+876400000+976170000+127500000+6821430000+75000000+42400000}}||$}} worth of damage. Typhoon Haiyan is currently the strongest and deadliest storm of the decade to have its name retired, while Typhoon Fitow is currently the costliest storm of the decade to have its name retired. {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} '''High winds''' can blow railway trains off tracks and cause accidents.<ref>{{cite article | url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/w5531100m065g489/ | title = Overturning Probability of Railway Vehicles under Wind Gust Loads | journal = Iutam Symposium on Dynamics and Control of Nonlinear Systems with Uncertainty | author = C. Proppe, C. Wetzel | year = 2007 | publisher = Springer}}</ref>
== Dangers of high winds ==
High winds can cause problems in a number of ways:
* blow trains off the tracks. * blow trains or wagons along the tracks and cause collisions. * cause pantographs and overhead wiring to tangle. * cause trees and other objects to fall onto the railway
== Preventative measures == Risks from high winds can be reduced by: * wind fences akin to [[snow sheds]] * lower profile of carriages * lowered [[centre of gravity]] of vehicles<ref>{{cite book | |first1=Klaus|last1=Kieper|first2=Reiner|last2=Preuß|first3=Elfriede|last3=Rehbein|title = Schmalspurbahn-Archiv | chapter = Bahnen in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern | page = 116 | publisher = Transpress | location = Berlin | year = 1982 | edition = 2nd| language=de}}</ref> * reduction in train speed or cancellation, at high winds * a wider rail [[Track gauge|gauge]] * improve overhead wiring with: ** regulated tension rather than fixed terminations ** shorter [[overhead lines|catenary]] spans ** solid conductors
== By country ==
=== {{flagu|Australia}} ===
* 1928 – 47 waggons blown along line at [[Tocumwal]] <ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article3961544 |title=SEVERE WINDSTORM. |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=8 October 1928 |accessdate=13 June 2013 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * 1931 – [[Kandos]] – wind blows level crossing gates closed in front of motor-cyclist <ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16816678 |title=LEVEL CROSSING ACCIDENT. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=27 August 1931 |accessdate=28 June 2015 |page=10 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * 1943 – Hobart, Tasmania; Concern that wind will blow over doubledeck trams on {{RailGauge|1067mm}} gauge if top deck enclosed.<ref> {{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article25936409 |title=Double-Deck Trams. |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart, Tas. |date=1 June 1943 |accessdate=24 April 2012 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * 2010 – Marla, South Australia; Small tornado blows over train.<ref>http://www.railpage.com.au/news-8530.htm</ref>
=== {{Flagicon|Austria}} Austria === * 1910 – Trieste (now in Italy) – train blown down embankment.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article72241525 |title=FATAL RAILWAY ACCIDENT. |newspaper=[[Northern Star (Australian newspaper)|Northern Star]] |volume=34 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=4 April 1910 |accessdate=26 November 2016 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
=== {{flagu|China}} ===
* [[Lanxin High-Speed Railway#Wind shed]] * [[List of rail accidents (2000–2009)]] – February 28, 2007 – Wind blows 10 passenger rail cars off the track near [[Turpan]], China.
=== {{flagu|Germany}} ===
* [[Rügen narrow-gauge railway]], 20 October 1936: derailment of a train, five injured<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29536000 |title=GALE DERAILS TRAIN. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=21 October 1936 |accessdate=4 May 2012 |page=16 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article52105580 |title=TRAIN DERAILED. |newspaper=[[The Examiner (Tasmania)|The Examiner]] |location=Launceston, Tas. |date=21 October 1936 |accessdate=11 May 2012 |page=8 Edition: DAILY |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
=== {{flagu|India}} ===
* One reason for choosing [[broad gauge]] in [[Rail transport in India|India]] for greater stability in high winds.
=== {{flagu|Ireland}} ===
* On the night of 30 January 1925, [[Londonderry_and_Lough_Swilly_Railway#Owencarrow_Viaduct_disaster|strong winds derailed carriages of a train crossing the Owencarrow Viaduct]] of the {{RailGauge|914mm}} gauge Londonderry and Lough Swilly Railway.
=== {{flagu|Japan}} ===
* [[Inaho]] * [[Amarube Viaduct]] * 1895 Gale blows train into sea <ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article79986462 |title=RAILWAY ACCIDENT. |newspaper=[[Zeehan and Dundas Herald]] |location=Tas. |date=31 July 1895 |accessdate=28 June 2015 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
=== {{flagu|New Zealand}} ===
* [[Rimutaka Incline railway accident]]
=== {{flagu|Norway}} ===
* [[Makrellbekken (station)#Wind related accident]] – blowing snow disoriented a tractor driver who collided with a train
=== {{flagu|South Africa}} ===
* Wind tangles overhead wiring.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.railwaysafrica.com/blog/2012/12/wind-stalls-cape-trains/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203011048/http://www.railwaysafrica.com/blog/2012/12/wind-stalls-cape-trains/ |archivedate=3 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Wind stalls Cape trains </ref>
=== {{flagu|United Kingdom}} ===
* [[Tay Bridge disaster]] 1879 * [[Chelford rail accident]] 1894 – during shunting * [[East Coast Main Line#Capacity problems|De-wirements]] on the [[East Coast Main Line]] * Leven Viaduct, Cumbria 27 February 1903 * [[Cheddington]] 2008 – two containers blown off train – design of "spigots" criticised.<ref>[[The Railway Magazine]] April 2015, p12</ref> * [[Moston, Manchester|Moston]] 2015 – [[Loading gauge#Out of gauge|out of gauge]] train hits platform, throwing stones onto other track.<ref>[[The Railway Magazine]] April 2015, p12</ref> * [[Scout Green]] 2015 – empty 30-foot ISA container blown off train <ref>[[The Railway Magazine]] April 2015, p12</ref>
=== {{flagu|United States}} === * During the storm of 31 March / 1 April 1892 a narrow-gauge passenger train of the Burlington and Northwestern railway was blown off the tracks in [[St Louis]], causing several persons to be injured.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article3542330 |title=NEWS BY MAIL. |newspaper=[[The Brisbane Courier]] |date=24 May 1892 |accessdate=12 May 2012 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * On 2 September 1911 tram services in Charleston, South Carolina, were suspended due to winds.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article74889432 |title=AMERICAN WIND STORM. |newspaper=[[The Northern Times]] |location=Carnarvon, WA |date=2 September 1911 |accessdate=25 April 2012 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * A [[January 2008 tornado outbreak|2008 tornado]] in [[Northern Illinois]] derailed a [[Union Pacific]] train.<ref>http://abc7chicago.com/archive/5875829/</ref> Dramatic footage of the event was captured by a camera mounted on the train.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LYubpuIe3cw</ref> * On April 27, 2015 a severe storm knocked several cars off the line while they were traveling across the [[Huey P. Long Bridge (Jefferson Parish)|Huey P. Long Bridge]], New Orleans, Louisiana, with no injuries. The footage of the complete accident was captured by a WGNO News Team on a dash cam.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.nola.com/weather/index.ssf/2015/04/train_blown_off_track_elmwood.html|title = Train cars blown off tracks on Huey P. Long Bridge, FOX 8 reports | author = Carlie Kollath Wells | newspaper = The Times-Picayune | date = April 27, 2015}}</ref>
One reason for choosing [[broad gauge]] (17% wider than standard gauge) for [[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]] was the greater stability in high winds and perhaps earthquakes.<ref>http://www.wirewd.com/wh/blog/bart_sucks/</ref><ref>http://www.thetransportpolitic.com/2010/01/06/crossing-the-bay-again-but-not-necessarily-with-bart/</ref><ref>http://homepage.mac.com/s_sloan/twar/ISSUE66/BODY.HTM{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Factors ==
* Lightweight trains * Narrow gauge * Aspects of the terrain <ref>{{cite web |url=http://wiki.climatechangeadaptation.org.au/tiki-index.php?page=Rail+vehicle+overturning |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222163523/http://wiki.climatechangeadaptation.org.au/tiki-index.php?page=Rail+vehicle+overturning |archivedate=22 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Tunnels <ref>http://www.yunlong.com.au/pdf/Liu-CFD.pdf</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Snowshed]]
== References ==

== External links ==
