revision.text:
'''Miscellaneous electric loads (MELs)''' in buildings are electric loads resulting from electronic devices not responsible for space heating, cooling, water heating, or lighting.<ref name=ashraeJune08>Roth, K., McKenney, K., Brodrick, J. "Small Devices, Big Loads." ASHRAE Journal. Vol. 60 No. 6. June 2008.</ref> MELs are produced by hard-wired and “plug-in” electrical devices, including [[entertainment center|home entertainment centers]], kitchen electronics such as microwaves and toaster ovens, bath items such as hair dryers and electric hot tubs, and others such as security systems and ceiling fans. MELs are gaining greater importance as home electronics become more sophisticated and more widespread, and miscellaneous electric use can only be expected to rise.<ref name=hendron>R. Hendron and M. Eastment, [http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy06osti/39551.pdf Development of an Energy-Savings Calculation Methodology for Residential Miscellaneous Electric Loads”], ACEEE Conference Paper, August 2006, pp.1, 4.</ref>
==Description== Miscellaneous electric use includes a diverse collection of electronics, such as power adapters, pool pumps, computer equipment, televisions, door bells, phone/fax machines, and many others. MELs usually do not include [[major appliance]]s such as refrigerators, stoves, dryers, etc. Although each device may draw a small amount of power, the large and steadily increasing number of devices can use a significant portion of a home’s energy. In the United States, MELs comprise nearly one quarter of residential energy use, larger than either heating or cooling energy end-use. In [[low-energy house]]s, this percentage increases dramatically, because MELs are often ignored while increasing whole-house [[efficient energy use|efficiency]].<ref name="ashraeJune08"/>
On average, home entertainment equipment, including televisions, audio equipment, and computers, make up about half of the total MELs in a United States home. About 13 percent of MELs come from devices in [[standby power|standby]] mode.
==Significance to zero-energy buildings== MELs can be lowered by using fewer electronic devices, choosing more efficient electronics (for example, [[Energy Star]] appliances), modifying occupant behavior and managing [[standby power]]. Still, MELs are a significant obstacle in creating [[zero-energy building]]s.<ref>National Renewable Energy Laboratory, [https://web.archive.org/web/20100806211721/http://www.bira.ws/projects/files/9C3b_Potential_Savings_Appliances.pdf “Final Report: Potential Savings in Miscellaneous Electric Loads from Use of Next Generation Appliances”] 29 March 2007, pp. 14.</ref> Heating, cooling and [[water heating]] energy loads can be reduced by improvements to the [[building envelope]], [[HVAC]] and water heating equipment, and [[Duct (HVAC)|air distribution system]]. MELs are more elusive, however, because of their diversity. Many miscellaneous electric devices that can be found in a large fraction of houses are smaller—for example toasters, televisions and internet routers, while larger power draws, such as well pumps or waterbed heaters, are present in only a small fraction of houses. Such variety makes it hard to find a systematic method of reducing MELs. If MELs cannot be reduced, the only way to counter them is with larger (and thus more costly) [[solar cell|solar]] arrays or other electricity generation methods.<ref name=hendron/>
==Energy feedback devices==
{{main | Home energy monitor}}
One reason MELs are difficult to reduce is because the use of small electric devices are controlled directly by a building’s inhabitants. One way to reduce MELs is by the use of energy feedback devices which report real-time energy use to a house’s occupants. The use of these devices has been tested in numerous studies which suggest whole-house savings of 5%-15%.<ref>Darby, Sarah, 2000, [http://www.electrisave.co.uk/cms/thesite/public/uploads/uploadsbank/1112705999_390.pdf "Making it obvious: designing feedback into energy consumption,"] Proceedings, 2nd International Conference on Energy Efficiency in Household Appliances and Lighting. Italian Association of Energy Economists, Naples, 2000. pp. 7</ref> With recent advances in technology, energy feedback devices can be purchased for $100–$150. Feedback devices allow people to identify and reduce [[standby power]] and as well as cut back on unnecessary power draws. In addition, occupants can see the effects of running pool pumps/heaters, supplemental space heaters, air conditioners, etc.<ref>Parker, D., Hoak, D., Cummings, J., [http://www.fsec.ucf.edu/en/publications/pdf/FSEC-CR-1742-08.pdf “Pilot Evaluation of Energy Savings from Residential Energy Demand Feedback Devices,”] Florida Solar Energy Center, January 2008.</ref> Energy feedback devices can further assist zero energy buildings, where it is desirable to align electric loads with photovoltaic panel output.<ref>Parker, D., Hoak, D., [http://www.fsec.ucf.edu/en/publications/pdf/FSEC-CR-1665-06.pdf “How Much Energy Are We Using? Potential of Residential Energy Feedback Devices,”] Proceedings of the ACEEE 2006 Summer Study on Energy Efficiency in Buildings, August 2006, pp. 2.</ref>
==See also== *[[The Energy Detective]] *[[Energy Star]] * [[Plug load]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Energy conservation]] [[Category:Low-energy building]] [[Category:Electric power]]

[[File:Trees in Moribane Forest, Bart Wursten.jpg|thumb|right|300px|View of the forest]] The 144 km<sup>2</sup> '''Moribane Forest Reserve''' ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]: Reserva Florestal de Moribane) which was proclaimed in 1957,<ref name=bri/> is a natural forest in the buffer zone of the 640 km<sup>2</sup> [[Chimanimani National Reserve]], and is situated 24 km north of [[Dombé]], in [[Sussundenga District]] of central [[Mozambique]].<ref name=fit>{{cite book |last1=Fitzpatrick |first1=Mary |title=Mozambique |date=2010 |publisher=Lonely Planet |location=Footscray, Vic. |isbn=1741048885 |page=114 |edition=3}}</ref> The mid to low-altitude tropical rain forest covers hilly country, from 400 to 550 metres in altitude,<ref name=mon/> on the eastern verges of the largest southern African forest of this type, altogether 820 km<sup>2</sup> in extent.<ref name=mon/> It can be reached using public transport from [[Sussundenga]].<ref name=fit/>
==Flora and fauna== {{Location map | Mozambique | relief = | caption = Location of the forest in [[Manica Province]], Mozambique | width = 175 | label = | mark = Green pog.svg | marksize = 8 | lat_deg = 19 | lat_min = 46 | lat_sec = 52 | lat_dir = S | lon_deg = 33 | lon_min = 18 | lon_sec = 08 | lon_dir = E }} ===Flora=== [[File:Oreobambos buchwaldii00.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[Oreobambos buchwaldii|Buchwa bamboo]] at Tava marsh in Moribane forest]] Müller et al. (2005) described two main vegetation types, namely a) moist, evergreen forest dominated by [[Newtonia buchananii|Forest newtonia]], [[Celtis mildbraedii|Chirinda stinkwood]], [[Erythrophleum suaveolens|Forest ordeal tree]] and [[Millettia stuhlmannii|Panga-panga]], and b) transitional forest on the northern verge of the forest, where the predominant species were [[Bersama abyssinica|Winged bersama]], Panga-panga, [[Pteliopsis myrtifolia|Two-winged pteleopsis]], [[Tabernaemontana elegans|Toad-tree]] and [[Xylopia longipetala|Bushveld bitterwood]].<ref name=mon/>
===Fauna=== Native mammals include [[African bush elephant|Bush elephant]], [[Bushbuck]], [[Red duiker]], [[Samango monkey]], [[Bushpig]] and several species of small carnivore.<ref name=bri>{{cite book |last1=Briggs |first1=Philip |title=Mozambique |date=2014 | page=222 |publisher=Bradt Travel Guides |isbn=1841624969}}</ref>
==History== Moribane forest was intensively exploited from the early 20th century onwards, initially for natural rubber derived from [[Landolphia kirkii|Rubber vine]], and subsequently for its native timber species, namely [[Khaya anthotheca|Red mahogany]], [[Milicia excelsa|Iroko]] and Panga-panga. As the 21st century approached, it was damaged by wildfires and shifting agriculture.<ref name=mon/> Despite past overexploitation, the widespread occurrence of saplings of [[Synsepalum brevipes|Stem-fruit miraculous-berry]], Forest newtonia, Iroko, Panga-panga and Forest ordeal tree, gives reason for hope that it will naturally regenerate.<ref name=mon>{{cite journal |last1=Monteiro |first1=José |last2=Dondeyne |first2=Stefaan |last3=Wursten |first3=Bart |last4=Bannerman |first4=James |last5=Meilby |first5=Henrik |last6=Sitoe |first6=Almeida |title=Vegetation composition of natural gaps in Moribane forest (Mozambique) |journal=African Journal of Ecology |date=December 2011 |volume=49 |issue=4 |pages=510–514 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2028.2011.01281.x |url=https://lirias.kuleuven.be/bitstream/123456789/314129/2/Monteiro-2011_Vegetation+composition+of+natural+gaps+in+Moribane+forest_AfrJEcol.pdf |accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref> [[Renamo]] had a stronghold in the area during the [[Mozambican Civil War]]. By the end of the war in 1992 the forest was largely intact, but its Bush elephant population was reduced.<ref name=dav>{{cite book |last1=Davis |first1=Ian; Corsane, Gerard; Davis, Peter |title=Making sense of place: multidisciplinary perspectives |date=2014 |publisher=Boydell & Brewer Ltd |isbn=1843838990 |page=297 |edition=Volume 7 of Heritage Matters}}</ref> While the local people had earlier observed taboos on hunting of elephant, they now had concerns about the recovering elephant population. Chief Mpunga argued that the relation between elephants and humans was spiritual, and people subsequently moved out of the area frequented by the elephants.<ref name=dav/>
==Facilities== Ndzou (i.e. Elephant) camp is a joint venture between Eco-Micaia and the local community,<ref name=fit/> which offers guided walks, and a chance of tracking of the shy, forest-living Bush elephants with a local guide. A number of forest trails can be taken from Ndzou camp or Mpunga ranger camp, varying from 4 to 12 km in length.<ref name=king>{{cite web |last1=Kingman |first1=Andrew |title=Discover the secrets of the forest at Ndzou Camp in Manica Province | date= 2 April 2013 |url=http://www.clubofmozambique.com/solutions1/sectionnews.php?secao=tourism&id=28179&tipo=one |website=clubofmozambique.com |accessdate=1 December 2014}}</ref> The Mpunga ranger camp, located 3 km to the south of Ndzou, caters only for visitors who bring their own tents and camping gear, and who are self-sufficient in terms of food.<ref name=bri/> Ndzou has thatched rondavels, tents, a three-bedroom house, restaurant and bar.<ref name=bri/>
==Site locations== {{GeoGroupTemplate}} * Moribane forest track <small>{{coord|19|44|30|S|33|19|20|E|region:MZ_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Forest track}}</small> * Mt Chinhaunguri <small>{{coord|19|44|17|S|33|22|38|E|region:MZ_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Mt Chinhaunguri}}</small> * Mpunga ranger & community camp <small>{{coord|19|44|36|S|33|21|22|E|region:MZ_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Mpunga camp}}</small> * Mpunga-Chinda-Zinguena communities <small>{{coord|19|42|42|S|33|24|33|E|region:MZ_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Local communities}}</small> * Ndzou camp <small>{{coord|19|44|01|S|33|20|15|E|region:MZ_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Ndzou camp}}</small> * Picada da dona Candida track <small>{{coord|19|45|45|S|33|18|44|E|region:MZ_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Picada da dona Candida}}</small> * "Ponta de Deus" <small>{{coord|19|43|27|S|33|20|19|E|region:MZ_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Ponta de Deus}}</small> * Tava marsh <small>{{coord|19|44|50|S|33|18|43|E|region:MZ_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Tava marsh}}</small>

{{Infobox mountain | name = Mount Garibaldi | photo = Mount Garibaldi.jpg | photo_caption = Mount Garibaldi as seen from [[Squamish, British Columbia|Squamish]] | elevation_m = 2678 | elevation_ref = <ref name="PP"> {{cite web |last=Edwards |first=Ben |title=Mt. Garibaldi, SW British Columbia, Canada |work=VolcanoWorld |date=November 2000 |url=http://volcano.oregonstate.edu/vwdocs/volc_images/north_america/canada/Final-Gar.html |accessdate=2008-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100731224109/http://volcano.oregonstate.edu/vwdocs/volc_images/north_america/canada/Final-Gar.html |archivedate=2010-07-31 |df= }}</ref> | prominence_m = 855 | prominence_ref = (estimated)<ref name=bivouac>{{cite bivouac|id=30|name=Mount Garibaldi|accessdate=2010-11-20}}</ref> | range = [[Garibaldi Ranges]] | listing = [[List of volcanoes in Canada]]{{clear}}[[List of Cascade volcanoes]] | location = [[Squamish, British Columbia|Squamish]], [[British Columbia]], Canada | map = Canada British Columbia | range_coordinates = | coordinates = {{coord|49|51|02|N|123|00|17|W|type:mountain_region:CA-BC_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = <ref name="AS"/> | topo = [[National Topographic System|NTS]] 92G/14 | type = [[Stratovolcano]] | age = [[Pleistocene]] | volcanic_arc/belt = [[Canadian Cascade Arc]]{{clear}}[[Garibaldi Volcanic Belt]] | last_eruption = 8060 BCE ± 500 years<ref name=Edwards2000/> | first_ascent = 1907 A. Dalton; W. Dalton; W. Dalton; A. King; T. Pattison; J.J. Trorey; G. Warren<ref name=bivouac/> | easiest_route = [[Glacier]] travel, snow climb }}
'''Mount Garibaldi''' is a potentially active<ref name="AA"/> [[stratovolcano]] in the [[Sea to Sky Country]] of [[British Columbia]], {{convert|80|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} north of [[Vancouver]], British Columbia, [[Canada]]. Located in the southernmost [[Coast Mountains]], it is one of the most recognized peaks in the [[British Columbia Coast|South Coast]] region, as well as British Columbia's best known volcano.<ref name="ASD"/><ref name="IK"/> It lies within the [[Garibaldi Ranges]] of the [[Pacific Ranges]].
This heavily [[erosion|eroded]] [[Lava dome|dome]] complex occupies the southwest corner of [[Garibaldi Provincial Park]] overlooking the town of [[Squamish, British Columbia|Squamish]].<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> It is the only major [[Pleistocene]] age volcano in [[North America]] known to have formed upon a glacier.<ref>{{cite book | last = Armitage | first = Doreen | title = Around the Sound: A History of Howe Sound-Whistler | publisher = Harbour Publishing | year = 2001 | pages = | url = http://www.harbourpublishing.com/excerpt/AroundtheSound/103 | isbn = 978-1-55017-235-5 | oclc = 56329598}}</ref> Although part of the [[Garibaldi Volcanic Belt]] within the [[Cascade Volcanic Arc]], it is not considered part of the [[Cascade Range]].<ref name="DG">{{cite web|title=Garibaldi volcanic belt |work=Catalogue of Canadian volcanoes |publisher=[[Geological Survey of Canada]] |date=2008-02-13 |url=http://cgc.rncan.gc.ca/volcanoes/cat/belt_garibaldi_e.php |accessdate=2008-05-10 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061023030758/http://cgc.rncan.gc.ca/volcanoes/cat/belt_garibaldi_e.php |archivedate=2006-10-23 |df= }}</ref>
== Human history ==
=== Indigenous people === To [[Squamish people]], the local [[Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast|indigenous people]] of this territory, the mountain is called ''Nch'kay''. In their [[Squamish language|language]] it means "Dirty Place" or "Grimy One".<ref name="STUS">{{cite paper | author = Yumks | author2 = Reimer, Rudy | title = Squamish Traditional Use Study: Squamish Traditional Use of Nch’kay Or the Mount Garibaldi and Brohm Ridge Area | version = DRAFT | publisher = First Heritage Archaeological Consulting | date = April 2003 | url = http://www.llbc.leg.bc.ca/public/PubDocs/bcdocs/414673/d24044/1181338763782_401d3802844e42babeb6eb41577ab95b.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2008-04-27}}</ref> This name of the mountain refers to the muddy water in the [[Cheekye River]].<ref name="AS"/> This mountain, like others located in the area, is considered sacred for it plays an important part in their [[History of the Squamish people|history]]. In their [[oral tradition|oral history]], they passed down a story of the [[Deluge (mythology)|flood]] covering the land. During this time, only two mountains peaked over the water, and this mountain was one of them. It was here that the remaining survivors of the flood latched their canoes to the peak and waited for the waters to subside.<ref name="STUS"/> The mountain also serves as weather indicator to the people, as when clouds cover the face of the mountain, it signals the coming of rain or snow.<ref name="SNCL">{{cite conference | first1 = Rudy | last1 = Reimer | last2=Yumks | title = Squamish Nation Cognitive Landscapes | booktitle = 39th Annual Canadian Archaeological Conference | pages = 4–5 | publisher = | date = April 2003| location = | url = http://archaeologywithoutreserve.com/Reimer%20CAA%202006%20Paper.pdf | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081219153603/http://archaeologywithoutreserve.com/Reimer%20CAA%202006%20Paper.pdf | archivedate=2008-12-19|format=PDF| doi = | accessdate = 2008-05-19}}</ref> Cultural ceremonial use, hunting, trapping and plant gathering occur around the Mount Garibaldi area, but the most important resource was a [[Stone tool|lithic]] material called [[obsidian]].<ref name="STUS2">{{cite paper | author1 = Yumks | author2 = Reimer, Rudy | title = Squamish Traditional Use Study: Squamish Traditional Use of Nch’kay Or the Mount Garibaldi and Brohm Ridge Area | version = DRAFT | publisher = First Heritage Archaeological Consulting | date = April 2003 | url = http://www.llbc.leg.bc.ca/public/PubDocs/bcdocs/414673/d24044/1181338763782_401d3802844e42babeb6eb41577ab95b.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2008-05-19 | page = 8}}</ref> Obsidian is a black volcanic glass that was used to make knives, chisels, [[adze]]s, and other sharp tools in pre-contact times. This material appears in sites dated to 10,000 years ago up to [[protohistoric]] time periods. The source for this material is found in upper parts of the mountain area in higher elevations that surround the mountain range.<ref name="SNCL"/>
=== Later history === British Explorer [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] [[George Vancouver]] reached [[Howe Sound]] in June 1792 and became the first European to see the mountain. During this time George Vancouver met and traded with the local natives in the area.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Squamish BC Canada|url=http://www.bctravel.com/squamish/index.html |title=Welcome To Squamish – British Columbia Canada|accessdate=2008-04-26}}</ref>
[[Image:Giuseppe Garibaldi portrait2.jpg|thumb|right|Mount Garibaldi was named after [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]] in 1860]] In 1860, while carrying out a survey of Howe Sound on board the [[Royal Navy]] survey ship [[HMS Plumper (1848)|HMS ''Plumper'']], Captain [[George Henry Richards]] was impressed by a gigantic mountain<!--did he use that term?--> dominating the view to the northeast. Captain Richards, and his officers, renamed the mountain after the Italian military and political leader [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]], who that year had succeeded in unifying [[Italy]] by patriating [[Sicily]] and [[Naples]].<ref name="DF">{{cite web|publisher=Government of British Columbia |url=http://www.env.gov.bc.ca/bcparks/explore/parkpgs/garibaldi/ |title=Garibaldi Provincial Park |accessdate=2008-07-03}}</ref> In August 1907, the [[Vancouver]] mountaineers A. Dalton, W. Dalton, A. King, T. Pattison, J.J. Trorey, and G. Warren reached the summit of Mount Garibaldi.<ref name="AS">{{Cite bcgnis|id=5329 |title=Mount Garibaldi}}</ref> The views from the peak inspired the establishment of summer climbing camps at [[Garibaldi Lake]].<ref name="DF"/> This early interest led to the creation in 1920 of a park reserve.<ref name="DF"/>
In 1927, Garibaldi was made into a large wilderness park called [[Garibaldi Provincial Park]]. Named after Mount Garibaldi, this 1,946.5 square kilometre park was established to protect the rich geological history, diverse vegetation, iridescent waters, abundant wildlife, and rugged mountains, many of which are capped by glaciers.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Shangaan Webservices Inc.|url=http://www.britishcolumbia.com/parks/?id=49 |title=BC Parks – Garibaldi Provincial Park, Sea to Sky Hwy, Whistler, British Columbia|accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref>
When skiing caught on in the 1940s, Vancouver skiers began to search the [[glacier]]s and rugged mountains within the park. Early skiing was limited to the more easily reached area around [[Garibaldi Lake]].<ref name="GZ"/> In the winter of 1944, a club group completed the first possible ski of Mount Garibaldi.<ref name="GZ"/> The famous mountaineers [[Don Munday|Don]] and [[Phyllis Munday]] completed lots of tracks additionally.<ref name="GZ"/> In the 1944–45 ''Canadian Alpine Journal'', the Mundays reported a ski attempt on Mount Garibaldi with Phil Brook, who was a friend of the Mundays.<ref name="GZ"/> They skied on Sphinx Glacier and scrabbled Panorama Ridge just north of [[Garibaldi Lake]] during the same trip. Most importantly, during this period a road was built on Paul Ridge near the small community of [[Squamish, British Columbia|Squamish]] at the north end of [[Howe Sound]], thereby affording better vehicle approach to the highlands near Mount Garibaldi.<ref name="GZ"/> With easier access Vancouver skiers spent even more time on the glaciers of Mount Garibaldi. The result of this was the formation in the 1940s of the Garibaldi Névé Traverse, an overnight adventure that (weather permitting) can include a fine descent of Mount Garibaldi.<ref name="GZ">{{cite book|publisher=The Mountaineers Books|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QHazBirR1hAC&pg=PA93|title=Wild Snow: A Historical Guide to North American Ski Mountaineering|first=Louis W. | last=Dawson | isbn=978-0-930410-81-0|date=1998}}</ref>
== Subsidiary peaks == [[File:MtGaribaldi-NorthFace-TheTable.jpg|thumb|right|The north face of Mount Garibaldi rises above [[The Table]] and [[Garibaldi Lake]] ]]
The broad top of Mount Garibaldi contains three named peaks. The highest peak is named as the mountain itself, reaching {{convert|2678|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} above sea level.<ref name="CD"/> The second highest peak is the sharp pyramid of [[Atwell Peak]] at the southern edge of the summit plateau, which reaches a height of {{convert|2655|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} and lies on the southwest end of Garibaldi Provincial Park.<ref name="UU"/> This peak is named after Atwell Duncan Francis Joseph King, leader of the first ascent of Mount Garibaldi in 1907.<ref name="UU">{{cite bcgnis|id=9850 |name=Atwell Peak|accessdate=2008-07-06}}</ref> The lowest of the three is the rounded Dalton Dome, {{convert|2653|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} high, west of the highest summit.<ref name="AJK">{{Cite bcgnis|id=7564 |title=Dalton Dome}}</ref> This peak is named after Arthur Tinniswood Dalton, one of the guides of the 1907 ascent.<ref name="AJK"/>
A feature on the north side of the mountain, known as The Tent, reaches {{convert|2465|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} and lies in Garibaldi Provincial Park.<ref>{{Cite bcgnis|id=14967 |title=Tent, The (peak)}}</ref> Another minor summit on the south side of the mountain, {{convert|2056|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} high, is known as Diamond Head (sometimes Little Diamond Head) for its resemblance to [[Diamond Head, Hawaii|Diamond Head]] in [[Hawaii]].<ref>{{Cite bcgnis|id=17301 |title=Diamond Head (mountain)}}</ref> Diamond Head was the site of a ski proposal and small lodge, now derelict. On the northwest side of Mount Garibaldi, Brohm Ridge lies outside the western boundary of Garibaldi Provincial Park.<ref>{{Cite bcgnis|id=1120 |title=Brohm Ridge}}</ref> The Sharkfin sticks up out of the Warren Glacier on the northeast side of the mountain with a height of {{convert|2000|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, just northeast of [[Squamish, British Columbia|Squamish]].<ref>{{Cite bcgnis|id=14965 |title=Sharkfin, The (spur)}}</ref> Columnar Peak rises on the south side of the mountain with a height of {{convert|1826|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, just southwest of Mamquam Lake at southwest end of Garibaldi Provincial Park.<ref>{{Cite bcgnis|id=37964 |title=Columnar Peak}}</ref> Two [[pinnacle]]s of [[volcanic rock]] {{convert|5|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} south of Mount Garibaldi's summit, which attain heights of {{convert|1816|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|1823|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, have been known as The Gargoyles since 1978.<ref>{{Cite bcgnis|id=5320 |title=Gargoyles, The (peaks)}}</ref>
== Glaciers and icefields ==
Two pocket glaciers lie right below the east side of [[Atwell Peak]], the [[Diamond Glacier (British Columbia)|Diamond Glacier]] to the southeast and the upper Bishop Glacier to the northeast. Straight north of Atwell toward Mount Garibaldi lies a small, high-elevation ice cap called the Cheekye Glacier, the name of which is associated with [[Cheekye River]].<ref>{{Cite bcgnis|id=4986 |title=Cheekeye Glacier}}</ref>
A large [[icefield]] lies on the eastern and northern flanks of Mount Garibaldi called the [[Garibaldi Névé]].<ref>{{Cite bcgnis|id=5328 |title=Garibaldi Névé}}</ref> Its drainage is to the east into the [[Pitt River]], to the southwest into [[Garibaldi Lake]].<ref name="QW">{{cite web|publisher=Bivouac.com – The Canadian Mountain Encyclopedia |url=http://www.bivouac.com/ArxPg.asp?ArxId=1318|title=Garibaldi Neve|accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref> It has an area of 35 km<sup>2</sup><ref name="QW"/> and is an area of substantial snowfall with more than {{convert|5|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} in many winters. The Garibaldi Névé is usually accessed from the south through the Bishop Glacier or from the north through the Sentinel Glacier.<ref name="QW"/> <!--mention of other ski proposals should be in this article-->
== Climbing and recreation == [[Image:Mount Garibaldi3.jpg|thumb|right|Mount Garibaldi and The Table as seen from [[The Black Tusk]].]]
[[Mountaineering|Mountain climbing]] on Mount Garibaldi is fairly difficult; it is fairly steep-sided and involves climbing very loose rotten [[lava]] and [[volcanic ash]]. Fortunately, Mount Garibaldi has large areas of massive glaciation and extensive snowfields. The eastern and northern flanks of the mountain are smothered by the [[Garibaldi Névé]] where the finest climbing opportunities exist, making the easiest route a [[glacial]] travel or snow climb.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mt. Garibaldi|publisher=Canada West Mountain School|date=2008-03-07|url=http://www.themountainschool.com/climb-mount-garibaldi.html|accessdate=2008-05-13|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509084856/http://www.themountainschool.com/climb-mount-garibaldi.html|archivedate=2008-05-09}}</ref> Routes keep mostly to the alpine [[glacier]]s and snow slopes, which are abundant in winter and spring, but eventually melt in late spring and commonly vanish after June or July of most years.<ref name="AKO">{{cite web|publisher=Government of British Columbia|url=http://www.env.gov.bc.ca/bcparks/explore/parkpgs/garibaldi/garibaldi_brochure.pdf |format=PDF|title=Garibaldi Provincial Park|accessdate=2008-07-14}}</ref> After the snow and ice melts, fissures and fractures can pose difficulty and danger, and avalanches from higher peaks of the mountain are a hazard.<ref name="AKO"/> For this reason, early season, cold-weather ascents are recommended for most routes up Garibaldi.
[[Hiking]], [[photography]], and [[camping]] are popular in the Garibaldi area. Several trailheads provide access to the backcountry.<ref name="CU">{{cite web|publisher=Government of British Columbia|url=http://www.env.gov.bc.ca/bcparks/explore/parkpgs/garibaldi/ |title=Garibaldi Provincial Park|accessdate=2013-03-26}}</ref> In mid to late summer, visitors pass through meadows of wildflowers along alpine trails. Garibaldi Provincial Park is also popular for winter sports, including backcountry skiing and snowshoeing.
== Geology == [[Image:Atwell Peak 2.jpg|thumb|left|[[Atwell Peak]] ]] Mount Garibaldi lies within the [[Coast Plutonic Complex]], which is the single largest contiguous [[granite]] outcropping in North America.<ref name="ZZ"/> The [[intrusion|intrusive]] and [[metamorphic rock]]s extend approximately {{convert|1800|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} along the coast of British Columbia, the [[Alaska Panhandle]] and southwestern [[Yukon]]. This is a remnant of a once vast [[volcanic arc]] called the ''Coast Range Arc'' that formed as a result of [[subduction]] of the [[Farallon Plate|Farallon]] and [[Kula Plate]]s during the [[Jurassic]]-to-[[Eocene]] periods.<ref name="ZZ">{{cite web|publisher=Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture|url=http://www.washington.edu/burkemuseum/geo_history_wa/Coast%20Range%20Episode.htm |title=The Coast Range Episode (115 to 57 million years ago)|accessdate=2008-04-09}}</ref> In contrast, Garibaldi, [[Mount Meager massif|Meager]], [[Mount Cayley massif|Cayley]] and [[Silverthrone Caldera|Silverthrone]] areas are of recent volcanic origin.<ref name="DG"/>
Mount Garibaldi is one of the few Cascade volcanoes that is made exclusively of [[dacite]] ([[Glacier Peak]] is the other).<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> The [[mountain]] has a unique asymmetrical shape because its main cone was constructed atop part of a large [[glacier]] system associated with the [[Cordilleran Ice Sheet]] that has since melted away.<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> Unlike many of the other Cascade volcanoes to the south, Garibaldi does not dominate the surrounding landscape, which consists of many high, rugged peaks. Many residents of Vancouver are therefore not aware that there is a volcano closer to the city than the more easily visible [[Mount Baker]] in Washington State.
=== Origins === [[Image:Garibaldi Volcanic Belt-en.svg|thumb|right|350px|Map of the [[Garibaldi Volcanic Belt]] centres, including the Mount Garibaldi area.]] Mount Garibaldi began erupting about 250,000 years ago and has grown steadily since then.<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> Like all of the Cascade volcanoes, Mount Garibaldi has its origins in the [[Cascadia subduction zone]]—a long convergent plate boundary that stretches from mid-[[Vancouver Island]] to [[Northern California]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=The Pacific Northwest Seismic Network |url=http://www.pnsn.org/HAZARDS/CASCADIA/cascadia_zone.html |title=The Cascadia Subduction Zone – What is it? How big are the quakes? How Often? |accessdate=2008-05-13 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509074102/http://www.pnsn.org/HAZARDS/CASCADIA/cascadia_zone.html |archivedate=2008-05-09 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The subduction zone separates the [[Juan de Fuca Plate|Juan de Fuca]], [[Explorer Plate|Explorer]], [[Gorda Plate|Gorda]] and [[North American Plate]]s. Here, the [[oceanic crust]] of the [[Pacific Ocean]] sinks beneath [[North America]] at a rate of {{convert|40|mm|in}} per year.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=State of California: Department of Conservation|url=http://www.consrv.ca.gov/index/news/2006%20News%20Releases/Pages/NR2006-04_1906_Quake_Reminder_to_Prepare.aspx |title=1906 Earthquake A Reminder to Be Prepared|accessdate=2008-05-11}}</ref> Hot [[magma]] upwelling above the descending oceanic plate creates volcanoes, and each individual volcano erupts for a few million years.
The [[subduction zone]] has existed for at least 37 million years, and has created a line of volcanoes called the [[Cascade Volcanic Arc]] which stretches over {{convert|1000|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} along the subduction zone.<ref name="ASD">{{cite web|url=http://www.washington.edu/burkemuseum/geo_history_wa/Cascade%20Episode.htm |title=The Cascade Episode |author1=Figge, John |author2=Townsend, Cathy |website=burkemuseum.org |date=October 2002 |accessdate=2008-05-11}}</ref> Several volcanoes in the arc are potentially active.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Dan Dzurisin, Peter H. Stauffer, James W. Hendley II|url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/1997/fs165-97/ |title=Living With Volcanic Risk in the Cascades|accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref> [[Lassen Peak]] in California, which last erupted in 1921, is the southernmost historically active volcano in the arc, while the [[Mount Meager massif]], just north of Mount Garibaldi, which erupted about 2,350 years ago, is generally considered the northernmost.<ref>{{cite gvp |vnum=1200-18- |title=Meager|accessdate=2008-05-11}}</ref> A few isolated volcanic centres northwest of the Mount Meager massif, such as the [[Silverthrone Caldera]], which is a circular {{convert|20|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} wide, deeply dissected [[caldera]] complex, are considered by some geologists to be the northernmost member of the arc.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Geological Survey of Canada|url=http://dsp-psd.communication.gc.ca/Collection/M44-2001-A11E.pdf|format=PDF|title=Preliminary petrography and chemistry of the Mount Cayley volcanic field, British Columbia|accessdate=2008-05-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219153514/http://dsp-psd.communication.gc.ca/Collection/M44-2001-A11E.pdf|archivedate=2008-12-19|df=}}</ref>
=== Structure === [[Image:Mount Garibaldi topographic map-en.svg|thumb|right|300px|Topographic map of the Garibaldi area]]
Mount Garibaldi is the largest volcano in southernmost British Columbia. Like other [[stratovolcano]]es, it is composed of many layers of hardened lava, [[tephra]], and volcanic ash. Eruptions are explosive in nature, and the most common form is the [[Peléan eruption|Peléan]] style, which involves [[viscous]] [[magma]], glowing avalanches of hot [[volcanic ash]] and [[pyroclastic flow]]s.<ref name="PP"/><ref name="AW"/> The source magma of this rock is classified as [[acid]]ic, having high to intermediate levels of [[silica]] (as in [[rhyolite]], [[dacite]], or [[andesite]]).<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Petty M. Donna |url=http://www.scetv.org/education/ntti/pdf/2004pdf/Volcanos-TharSheBlowsA2.pdf |format=PDF |title=Activity Sheet 2: Eruption Primer |accessdate=2008-07-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080717000234/http://www.scetv.org/education/ntti/pdf/2004pdf/Volcanos-TharSheBlowsA2.pdf |archivedate=2008-07-17 |df= }}</ref> The tephra deposits have lower volume and range than the corresponding [[Plinian eruption|Plinian]] and [[Vulcanian eruption]]s.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=VolcanoWorld|url=http://volcano.und.edu/vwdocs/vwlessons/kinds/kinds.html |title=Kinds Of Volcanic Eruptions |accessdate=2008-05-15|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080515231119/http://volcano.und.edu/vwdocs/vwlessons/kinds/kinds.html |archivedate = May 15, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Mount Garibaldi is known both for the very high quality exposures of its internal structure and for its conspicuous [[topography|topographic]] anomalies, which can be attributed to the growth of the mountain onto a large glacier system and the subsequent collapse of the flanks of the volcano with the melting of the ice.<ref name="SLV"/> The western flanks of the mountain expose basement rocks, sheared and altered [[quartz]] [[diorite]], carved by streams and glaciers into a rugged topography with relief up to {{convert|1800|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="SLV"/> Valleys in this jagged surface have been filled with 0.52 to 0.22 million year old [[dacite]] and [[andesite]] flows, [[tuff]] [[breccia]]s, and [[lava dome|domes]], precursors of the activity at Mount Garibaldi.<ref name="SLV"/> About {{convert|0.8|cumi|km3|1}} of material remains in the volcano.<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> In modern times, the apron of material around the volcano's main vent extends at least {{convert|4.8|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} from its source in places that were covered by ice. In other areas its extent is less and its slope is steeper.
Stratovolcanoes are a common feature of subduction zones.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire|url=http://www.uwec.edu/jolhm/EH3/Group1/Website/Stratovolcano.html |title=Stratovolcanoes |accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref> The magma that forms them arises when water, which is trapped both in hydrated minerals and in the porous [[basalt]] rock of the upper oceanic crust, is released into [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]] rock of the [[asthenosphere]] above the sinking oceanic slab. The release of water from hydrated minerals is termed "dewatering", and occurs at specific pressure/temperature conditions for specific minerals as the plate subducts to lower depths. The water freed from the subducting slab lowers the [[melting point]] of the overlying mantle rock, which then undergoes partial melting and rises due to its density relative to the surrounding mantle rock, and pools temporarily at the base of the [[lithosphere]]. The magma then rises through the [[crust (geology)|crust]], incorporating silica rich crustal rock, leading to a final intermediate composition. When the magma nears the surface it pools in a [[magma chamber]] under the volcano. The relatively low pressure of the magma allows water and other [[volatility (chemistry)|volatiles]] (CO<sub>2</sub>, S<sup>2−</sup>, Cl<sup>−</sup>) dissolved in the magma to begin to come out of solution, much like when a bottle of [[carbonated water]] is opened.<ref name="QYT">{{cite web|publisher=USGS|url=http://vulcan.wr.usgs.gov/Glossary/StratoVolcano/description_composite_volcano.html |title=Composite Volcanoes and Stratovolcanoes, Subduction-Zone Volcanoes |accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref> Once a critical volume of magma and gas accumulates, the obstacle provided by the [[volcanic cone]] is overcome, leading to a sudden [[explosive eruption]].<ref name="QYT"/>
=== Ancestral stages of eruptive activity === [[Image:Mount Garibaldi outline.jpg|thumb|right|Red outline indicates the ancestral volcano]] The mountain grew in three phases. Garibaldi's first phase resulted in the creation of a broad composite cone made of dacite and [[breccia]] that has been [[potassium-argon dating|potassium-argon dated]] to 250,000 years old.<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> Parts of this "proto-Garibaldi" or ancestral volcano are exposed on Garibaldi's lower northern and eastern flanks and on the upper {{convert|240|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} of Brohm Ridge. Around where Columnar Peak and possibly [[Glacier Pikes]] are now located, a series of coalescing dacite [[lava dome]]s were constructed. During the ensuing long period of dormancy, the [[Cheekye River]] cut a deep valley into the cone's western flank that was later filled with a glacier.<ref name="88HarrisSL"/>
After reaching its maximum extent the Cheekye Glacier along with part of the area's [[ice sheet]] were covered with [[volcanic ash]] and fragmented debris from Garibaldi. This period of growth began with the eruption of the [[Atwell Peak]] plug dome from a ridge surrounded by the several thousand foot ice sheet. As the plug dome rose, massive sheets of broken lava crumbled as [[Scree|talus]] down its sides. Numerous [[Peléan eruption|Peléan]] [[pyroclastic flow]]s (consisting of a super-heated mix of [[gas]], ash, and [[pumice]]) accompanied these cooler avalanches, forming a fragmental cone {{convert|6.3|km3|cumi|1}} in volume and an overall slope of 12 to 15 degrees. ([[Erosion]] has since steepened this slope.)<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> Some of the glacial ice was melted by the eruptions, forming a small [[lake]] against Brohm Ridge's southern arm. The volcanic [[sandstone]]s seen today atop Brohm Ridge were created by ash settling in this lake.<ref name="88HarrisSL">{{cite book | last = Harris | first = Stephen L. | title = Fire Mountains of the West: The Cascade and Mono Lake Volcanoes| publisher = [[Mountain Press Publishing Company]] | year= 1988 | pages= 283–288 | isbn = 0-87842-220-X }}</ref> [[Image:Elfin Lakes, Opal Cone.jpg|thumb|right|Elfin Lakes and [[Opal Cone]] on Garibaldi's southeast flank]]
Glacial overlap was most significant on the west and somewhat to the south.<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> Subsequent melting of the ice sheet and its component glaciers initiated a series of avalanches and [[mudflow]]s on Garibaldi's western flank that moved nearly half of the original cone's volume into the Squamish Valley.<ref name="CD">{{cite gvp | vnum=1200-20-|title=Garibaldi|accessdate= 2008-04-27}}</ref> This series of [[debris flow]]s carried {{convert|2.5|km3|cumi|1}} of the mountain into the Squamish Valley where it covers {{convert|10|sqmi|km2|0}} to a thickness of about {{convert|300|ft|m|0}}.<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> Gaps left by melting ice caused minor to moderate cone distortion where the ice sheet was thin and major distortion where it was thick. The ice was thickest in and thus cone distortion was greatest over the buried Cheekye valley.
Soon before or after the buried ice had melted away, [[dacite]] lava quietly erupted from [[Opal Cone]] southeast of the [[Atwell Peak]] plug dome 10,700 to 9,300 years ago<ref name="PP"/> and flowed {{convert|20|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} down [[Ring Creek]] on Garibaldi's southern and southwestern flanks without encountering any residual glacial ice.<ref name="SLV">{{cite book|last1=Wood | first1=Charles A. | last2=Kienle|first2=Jürgen| chapter= | pages= | title=Volcanoes of North America: United States and Canada | year=2001 | edition= | publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] | location=[[Cambridge]], [[England]]| isbn= 978-0-521-43811-7|oclc= 27910629}}</ref> One of the lava flows traveled down a 30% to 35% grade over the landslide scar on the western flank.<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> About {{convert|0.15|cumi|km3|2}} of dacite erupted in Garibaldi's third period of activity.<ref name="88HarrisSL"/> This lava forms a thin layer of solid rock on the southern and western sides of the volcano and contains well-defined lava flow margin levees.<ref name="PP"/> The Ring Creek lava flow is very unusual because lengthy lava flows are usually attained by fluid [[basalt]] flows, but the Ring Creek flow is [[dacite]].<ref name="AW"/>
=== Current activity === [[File:The Table.jpg|thumb|right|[[The Table]] and Mount Garibaldi as seen from The Black Tusk Meadows]] Mount Garibaldi is one of the eleven Canadian volcanoes most strongly associated with recent [[Seismology|seismic activity]]; the others are [[Castle Rock (volcano)|Castle Rock]],<ref name="IK"/> [[Mount Edziza]],<ref name="IK"/> [[Mount Cayley massif]],<ref name="IK"/> [[Hoodoo Mountain]],<ref name="IK"/> [[The Volcano (British Columbia)|The Volcano]],<ref name="IK"/> [[Crow Lagoon]],<ref name="IK"/> [[Silverthrone Caldera]],<ref name="IK"/> [[Mount Meager massif]],<ref name="IK"/> [[Wells Gray-Clearwater Volcanic Field]]<ref name="IK">{{cite web|last1=Hickson |first1=C.J. |last2=Ulmi |first2=M. |title=Volcanoes of Canada |work= |publisher=Natural Resources Canada |date=2006-01-03 |url=http://www.bcminerals.ca/pdf/CanadianVolcanoes-CH2005.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2007-01-10 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060528051236/http://www.bcminerals.ca/pdf/CanadianVolcanoes-CH2005.pdf |archivedate=2006-05-28 |df= }}</ref> and [[Nazko Cone]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Natural Resources Canada |url=http://earthquakescanada.nrcan.gc.ca/nazko/nazko_chronology_e.php |title=Chronology of Events in 2007 at Nazko Cone |accessdate=2008-04-27 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20071205104714/http://earthquakescanada.nrcan.gc.ca/nazko/nazko_chronology_e.php |archivedate=2007-12-05 |df= }}</ref> The mountain is informally described as "dormant" ("asleep") because the mountain has not erupted in historic times, nor does it display [[fumarole|fumarolic]] activity like nearby [[Mount Baker]].<ref name="GHJ"/> However, seismic data suggests that these volcanoes still contain living [[magma]] plumbing systems, indicating possible future eruptive activity.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Geological Survey of Canada |url=http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/gscvol_e.php |title=Volcanoes of Canada: Volcanology in the Geological Survey of Canada |accessdate=2008-05-09 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061008200258/http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/gscvol_e.php |archivedate=2006-10-08 |df= }}</ref> Although the available data does not allow a clear conclusion, these observations are further indications that some of Canada's volcanoes are potentially active, and that their associated hazards may be significant.<ref name="AA"/> The seismic activity correlates both with some of Canada's most youthful volcanoes, and with long-lived volcanic centres with a history of significant explosive behavior, such as Mount Garibaldi.<ref name="AA"/> No [[hot spring]]s are known in the Garibaldi area like those found at the Mount Meager and Mount Cayley massifs, the other major volcanic complexes in the Garibaldi belt, although there are hints of anomalously high local heat flow in Table Meadows and elsewhere.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Glenn J. Woodsworth, P. Geo. |url=http://www.empr.gov.bc.ca/DL/ARISReports/27299.pdf |format=PDF |title=Geology and Geothermal Potential of the AWA Claim Group, Squamish, British Columbia |accessdate=2008-04-27 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219153526/http://www.empr.gov.bc.ca/DL/ARISReports/27299.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-19 |df= }}</ref>
== Volcanic hazards == [[Image:Squamish valley.jpg|thumb|left|Looking southward down the Squamish valley from the Siguard Creek trail lookout. Mount Garibaldi can be seen prominently in the background.]] Volcanic eruptions in Canada rarely cause fatalities because of their remoteness and low level of activity. The only known fatality due to volcanic activity in Canada occurred at the [[Tseax Cone]] in 1775, when a {{convert|22.5|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} long [[basalt]]ic lava flow travelled down the [[Tseax River|Tseax]] and [[Nass River]]s, destroying a [[Nisga'a]] village and killing approximately 2,000 people by [[volcanic gas]]es.<ref> {{cite web|title=Tseax Cone |work=Catalogue of Canadian volcanoes |publisher=[[Geological Survey of Canada]] |date=2005-08-19 |url=http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/cat/volcano_e.php?id=svb_tsx_107 |accessdate=2008-07-29 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060219232127/http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/cat/volcano_e.php?id=svb_tsx_107 |archivedate=2006-02-19 |df= }}</ref> Many towns and cities near Mount Garibaldi are home to over half of British Columbia's human population, and there is a likelihood that future eruptions will cause damage to populated areas, making Mount Garibaldi and other Garibaldi belt volcanoes a major hazard.<ref>{{cite web|title=Landslides and snow avalanches in Canada |work=Landslides |publisher=[[Geological Survey of Canada]] |date=2007-02-05 |url=http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/landslides/snow_e.php |accessdate=2008-07-29 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713225543/http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/landslides/snow_e.php |archivedate=2007-07-13 |df= }}</ref> There are significant hazards from almost all Canadian volcanoes that require hazard maps and emergency plans.<ref name="ZDI">{{cite web|title=Volcanology in the Geological Survey of Canada |work=Volcanoes of Canada |publisher=[[Geological Survey of Canada]] |date=2007-10-10 |url=http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/gscvol_e.php |accessdate=2008-07-29 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061008200258/http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/gscvol_e.php |archivedate=2006-10-08 |df= }}</ref> Volcanoes which exhibit significant seismic activity, such as Mount Garibaldi, appear to be most likely to erupt.<ref name="ZDI"/> A significant eruption of any of the Garibaldi belt volcanoes would significantly impact [[British Columbia Highway 99|Highway 99]] and communities like [[Pemberton, British Columbia|Pemberton]], [[Whistler, British Columbia|Whistler]] and [[Squamish, British Columbia|Squamish]], and possibly [[Vancouver]].<ref name="ZDI"/>
=== Explosive eruptions === [[Image:SquamishMain.jpg|thumb|right|Mount Garibaldi as seen from Squamish]] Explosive eruptions from Mount Garibaldi would pose a severe threat to the nearby communities of [[Whistler, British Columbia|Whistler]] and [[Squamish, British Columbia|Squamish]]. Although no [[Plinian eruption]]s have been identified in Garibaldi's eruptive history, even [[Peléan eruption]]s could create large amounts of ash that could significantly affect these local communities.<ref name="AW"/> Ash columns may rise to several hundred meters above the volcano, and due to its close proximity to [[Vancouver]] this could pose a threat for air traffic.<ref name="AW"/> Melting of leftover glacial ice covering the Mount Garibaldi area may cause [[flood]]s, [[lahar]]s, or [[debris flow]]s that could possibly threaten small communities such as [[Brackendale, British Columbia|Brackendale]].<ref name="AW"/> [[British Columbia Highway 99|Highway 99]] is already plagued by [[landslide]]s and debris flows from the steep rugged Coast Mountains.<ref name="AW"> {{cite web|title=Garibaldi volcanic belt: Garibaldi Lake volcanic field |work=Catalogue of Canadian volcanoes |publisher=[[Geological Survey of Canada]] |date=2008-02-13 |url=http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/cat/feature_garibaldi_e.php |accessdate=2008-04-29 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060219225103/http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/cat/feature_garibaldi_e.php |archivedate=2006-02-19 |df= }}</ref> An eruption creating floods could demolish sections of the highway. Flooding and debris flows could also have severe issues for the salmon fishery on the [[Squamish River|Squamish]], [[Cheakamus River|Cheakamus]], and [[Mamquam River|Mamquam]] [[river]]s.<ref name="AW"/> In addition, [[explosive eruption]]s and the associated ash column could cause short-and long-term water supply difficulties for Vancouver and most of the lower mainland.<ref name="AW"/> The catchment area for the Greater Vancouver watershed is close to the Garibaldi area.<ref name="AW"/> [[Pyroclastic fall]] could also have a deleterious effect on the ice fields to the east of Mount Garibaldi, causing more melting and spring flooding.<ref name="AW"/> This in turn could endanger water supplies from [[Pitt Lake]] as well as fisheries on the [[Pitt River]].<ref name="AW"/>
=== Lava flows === [[File:Ring Creek lava flow.jpg|thumb|right|Satellite photo of the Ring Creek lava flow]] The hazard from lava flows would be low to moderate because the nature of the lavas would prevent them from travelling far from their source, even though the [[Ring Creek]] lava flow ends only {{convert|6|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} from Squamish.<ref name="AW"/> Magma with high to intermediate levels of [[silica]] (as in [[andesite]], [[dacite]] or [[rhyolite]]) commonly move slowly and typically cover small areas to form steep-sided mounds called [[lava dome]]s.<ref name="IGJ">{{cite web|title=Lava Flows and Their Effects|url=http://volcanoes.usgs.gov/hazards/lava/index.php|author=USGS|accessdate=2007-07-29}}</ref> Lava domes often grow by the extrusion of many individual flows less than {{convert|30|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} thick over a period of several months or years.<ref name="IGJ"/> Such flows will overlap one another and typically move less than a few meters per hour.<ref name="IGJ"/> Lava flows with high to intermediate levels of silica rarely extend more than {{convert|8|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} from their source; for example, Garibaldi's {{convert|20|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} long Ring Creek [[dacite]] lava flow.
=== Landslides === In the past, Garibaldi has had large [[debris flow]]s. A section of the mountain collapsed into the [[Cheakamus River]] valley when the glacier Garibaldi was built on melted, creating a jagged unstable slope at the head of the [[Cheekye River]].<ref name="GHJ">{{cite web|title=Living in the shadow of volcanoes |work=Geoscape Vancouver |publisher=[[Natural Resources Canada]] |date=2008-01-04 |url=http://geoscape.nrcan.gc.ca/vancouver/living_e.php |accessdate=2008-07-05 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051125035850/http://geoscape.nrcan.gc.ca/vancouver/living_e.php |archivedate=2005-11-25 |df= }}</ref> Repeated landslides from this steep cliff have created a huge debris fan at the mouth of the Cheekye River just north of [[Brackendale, British Columbia|Brackendale]] called the [[Cheekye Fan]].<ref name="GHJ"/> Danger from future collapses have limited the growth of Brackendale onto the fan.<ref name="GHJ"/>
The steep northern edge of [[The Barrier]] in the Garibaldi area has partly collapsed several times, the most recent being in 1855–56.<ref name="AW"/> This collapse created a large boulder field below it, which gave [[Rubble Creek]] its name.<ref name="AW"/> Danger from future collapses prompted the provincial government to declare the area immediately below it unsafe for human habitation in 1981. This led to the evacuation of the small resort village of [[Garibaldi, British Columbia|Garibaldi]] nearby, and the relocation of residents to new recreational subdivisions away from the hazard zone.<ref name="AW"/> Although imminent danger is unlikely, special regulations exist to warn potential danger and to minimize the risk to life and property in the event of a landslide.<ref name="CU"/>
== Monitoring == [[Image:Mount Garibaldi1.jpg|thumb|right|Mount Garibaldi]] Currently, Mount Garibaldi is not monitored closely enough by the [[Geological Survey of Canada]] to ascertain how active the volcano's magma system is.<ref name="KIO">{{cite web|publisher=Natural Resources Canada |url=http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/mon_e.php |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yTgBuL9K?url=http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/volcanoes/mon_e.php |archivedate=2011-05-06 |title=Volcanoes of Canada: Monitoring volcanoes |accessdate=2008-05-19 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The existing network of [[seismometer|seismographs]] has been established to monitor tectonic earthquakes and is too far away to provide a good indication of what is happening beneath the mountain.<ref name="KIO"/> It may sense an increase in activity if the volcano becomes very restless, but this may only provide a warning for a large eruption.<ref name="KIO"/> It might detect activity only once the volcano has started erupting.<ref name="KIO"/>
A possible way to detect an eruption is studying Garibaldi's geological history since every volcano has its own pattern of behaviour, in terms of its eruption style, magnitude and frequency, so that its future eruption is expected to be similar to its previous eruptions.<ref name="KIO"/>
While there is a likelihood of Canada being critically affected by local or close by volcanic eruptions argues that some kind of improvement program is required.<ref name="AA"/> Benefit-cost thoughts are critical to dealing with natural hazards.<ref name="AA"/> However, a benefit-cost examination needs correct data about the hazard types, magnitudes and occurrences. These do not exist for volcanoes in British Columbia or elsewhere in Canada in the detail required.<ref name="AA"/>
Other volcanic techniques, such as hazard mapping, displays a volcano's eruptive history in detail and speculates an understanding of the hazardous activity that could possibly be expected in the future.<ref name="AA"/> At present no hazard maps have been created for Mount Garibaldi because the level of knowledge is insufficient due to its remoteness.<ref name="AA"/> A large volcanic hazard program has never existed within the Geological Survey of Canada.<ref name="AA"/> The majority of information has been collected in a lengthy, separate way from the support of several employees, such as [[volcanologist]]s and other geologic [[scientist]]s. Current knowledge is best established at the [[Mount Meager massif]] north of Mount Garibaldi and is likely to rise considerably with a temporary mapping and monitoring project.<ref name="AA"/> An intensive program classifying infrastructural exposure near all young Canadian volcanoes and quick hazard assessments at each individual volcanic edifice associated with recent seismic activity would be in advance and would produce a quick and productive determination of priority areas for further efforts.<ref name="AA"/>
[[Image:Mount Garibaldi4.jpg|thumb|left|Mount Garibaldi close up from Tantalus]] The existing network of seismographs to monitor tectonic earthquakes has existed since 1975, although it remained small in population until 1985.<ref name="AA"/> Apart from a few short-term seismic monitoring experiments by the Geological Survey of Canada, no volcano monitoring has been accomplished at Mount Garibaldi or at other volcanoes in Canada at a level approaching that in other established countries with historically active volcanoes.<ref name="AA"/> Active or restless volcanoes are usually monitored using at least three seismographs all within approximately {{convert|15|km|mi|0|abbr=on}}, and frequently within {{convert|5|km|mi|0|abbr=on}}, for better sensitivity of detection and reduced location errors, particularly for earthquake depth.<ref name="AA"/> Such monitoring detects the risk of an eruption, offering a forecasting capability which is important to mitigating volcanic risk.<ref name="AA"/> Currently Mount Garibaldi does not have a seismograph closer than {{convert|25|km|mi|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="AA"/> With increasing distance and declining numbers of seismographs used to indicate seismic activity, the prediction capability is reduced because earthquake location accuracy and depth decreases, and the network becomes less accurate.<ref name="AA"/> The inaccurate earthquake locations in the Garibaldi Volcanic Belt are a few kilometers, and in more isolated northern regions they are up to {{convert|10|km|mi|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="AA"/> The location magnitude level in the Garibaldi Volcanic Belt is about magnitude 1 to 1.5, and elsewhere it is magnitude 1.5 to 2.<ref name="AA"/> At carefully monitored volcanoes both the located and noticed events are recorded and surveyed immediately to improve the understanding of a future eruption.<ref name="AA"/> Undetected events are not recorded or surveyed in British Columbia immediately, nor in an easy-to-access process.<ref name="AA"/>
In countries like Canada it is possible that small precursor earthquake swarms might go undetected, particularly if no events were observed; more significant events in larger swarms would be detected but only a minor subdivision of the swarm events would be complex to clarify them with confidence as volcanic in nature, or even associate them with an individual volcanic edifice.<ref name="AA"/>
== Garibaldi Lake volcanic field == [[Image:Mount Garibaldi and Garibaldi Lake from 2150 meters.jpg|thumb|right|Mount Garibaldi, The Table and Garibaldi Lake viewed from {{convert|2150|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}]] {{main|Garibaldi Lake volcanic field}}
Mount Garibaldi is associated with a group of small volcanoes that form the Garibaldi Lake [[volcanic field]]. An unusual volcanic structure called [[The Table]] is located between [[Garibaldi Lake]] and Mount Garibaldi.<ref>{{Cite bcgnis|id=16718 |title=Table, The (mountain)}}</ref> This several-hundred-foot-high flat-topped volcano is made of layers of [[andesite|andesitic]] dacite that are arranged like a stack of more or less equal sized [[pancake]]s. The Table was formed in the early [[Holocene]] at a time when the Cordilleran [[ice sheet]] covered the region.<ref name="AH"/> As the volcano's lava rose it melted the part of the ice sheet above The Table's vent, creating space for the lava to move into. Repeated eruptions constructed the steep-walled stack of lava seen today.
[[The Black Tusk]] is a large spire of extensively eroded dark [[volcanic rock]] that is shaped like a [[Walrus]] [[tusk]]. It is considered to be the remnant of an [[extinct volcano|extinct]] [[andesite|andesitic]] [[stratovolcano]] which formed between about 1.3 and 1.1 million years ago.<ref name="AH"/>
[[Mount Price (British Columbia)|Mount Price]], west of Garibaldi Lake, 5 km south of The Black Tusk, was formed in three stages of activity, dating back 1.1 million years, the latest of which produced two large [[lava|lava flows]] from [[Clinker Peak]] during the early Holocene that ponded against the retreating continental [[ice sheet]] and formed [[The Barrier]], containing Garibaldi Lake.<ref name="AH">{{cite gvp |vnum=1200-19- |title=Garibaldi Lake|accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref>
[[Cinder Cone (British Columbia)|Cinder Cone]] stands {{convert|150|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} above a gap between two arms of Helmet Glacier on Garibaldi's flanks. During summer its [[Volcanic crater|crater]] is filled with a snow melt lake. {{-}}

revision.text:
The first '''[[Canada|Canadian]] National Ambient [[Air Quality]] Objectives''' were developed in the mid-1970s. These objectives were set for various [[air pollutants]]. The NAAQO had three levels indicating severity (maximum desirable, acceptable and tolerable levels) and also evaluated effect levels (maximum desirable, acceptable and tolerable levels).
In 1992, a review of the NAAQOs suggested that many air pollutants had no effect thresholds (e.g. [[ozone|tropospheric ozone]] or very low effect thresholds). As such, scientifically defensible effect levels could not be identified. In 2000, the revised NAAQOs framework specifies a '''Reference Level''', above which there are demonstrated effects on human health and/or the environment, and an '''Air Quality Objective''' (AQO), which is meant to be protective for the general public and environment and which also considers aspects of technical feasibility. This approach is different from how the [[National Ambient Air Quality Standards]] are set in the [[US]], where cost is explicitly not considered in the proposal to strengthen the air quality standards to protect human health and the environment. In addition, the US NAAQS are periodically reviewed, frequently strengthened, commonly enforced and allow serious legal penalties if the standards are not met. In contrast, the Canadian NAAQOs are infrequently reviewed, rarely strengthened, not enforced, and the only penalty for not meeting the Canadian NAAQOs is shame.
The original NAAQOs have not been formally revised to the new two-level system. As an interim approach, data are compared with the existing desirable and acceptable NAAQOs for sulphur dioxide, carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide and ozone.
The air quality objectives must be consistent with the [[Canadian Environmental Protection Act]] (CEPA) 1999. They must also be based on scientific principles, such as risk assessment and risk management. The NAAQOs are set by the federal government based on recommendations from a National Advisory Committee and Working Group on Air Quality Objectives and Guidelines. Provincial governments have the option of adopting these either as objectives or as enforceable standards according to their legislation.
==References== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130701195127/http://www.ec.gc.ca/rnspa-naps/default.asp?lang=En&n=24441DC4-1 Environment Canada's page on the NAAQOs], April 30, 2004 {{reflist}}
[[Category:Environmental law in Canada]] [[Category:Air pollution]] [[Category:Air pollution in Canada]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox Organization |name = National Centre for Antarctic and Ocean Research |image = |image_border = |size = <!-- default 200 --> |alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> |caption = |map = <!-- optional --> |msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 200px --> |malt = <!-- map alt text --> |mcaption = <!-- optional --> |abbreviation = NCAOR |motto = |formation = {{Start date and years ago|1998|05|25|df=yes}} |type = <!-- GO, NGO, IGO, INGO, etc --> |status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> |purpose = <!-- focus as e.g. humanitarian, peacekeeping, etc --> |headquarters = [[Vasco da Gama, Goa]] |location = |coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |region_served =India |membership = |language = <!-- official languages --> |leader_title = Director |leader_name = Dr M Ravichandran |main_organ = Governing Council |parent_organization = <!-- if one --> |affiliations = <!-- if any --> |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.ncaor.gov.in/ Official website] |remarks = }} The '''National Centre for Antarctic and Ocean Research''' (NCAOR) is an Indian [[research and development]] institution, situated in [[Vasco da Gama, Goa|Vasco]], [[Goa]].In July 2018 it has been renamed as THE NATIONAL CENTRE FOR POLAR AND OCEAN RESEARCH. It is an autonomous Institution of the Department of Ocean Development (DOD), [[Government of India]] which is responsible for administering the [[Indian Antarctic Program|Indian Antarctic Programme]] and maintains the Indian government's [[Antarctica|Antarctic]] [[research station]], [[Maitri]]. NCAOR was established on 25 May 1998, with [[Prem Pandey|Dr P C Pandey]]<ref name=NCAOR1>{{cite web | url=http://www.ncaor.gov.in/pages/view/391/395-professor-prem-chand-pandey | title= Professor Prem Chand Pandey | publisher=NCAOR | accessdate=5 February 2018}}</ref> as its founding director.<ref>[http://www.ncaor.nic.in/news_files/Ncaor_foundation_day.htm 10th Foundation day of NCAOR] Dr. P C Pandey stated as Founder and Former Director</ref><ref>[http://coraliitkgp.webs.com/faculty.htm "Dr. Prem Chand Pandey, Emeritus Profesor, Ph.D (Allahabad University), Founder Director NCAOR GOA, INDIA]. Centre for Oceans, Rivers, Atmosphere and Land Sciences [[IIT Kharagpur]] Faculty Page</ref><ref>[http://auaa.in/?page_id=31 Allahabad Registered(1860)Alumni Association-Proud Past] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120707073335/http://auaa.in/?page_id=31 |date=2012-07-07 }} Dr. P. C. Pandey, NCAOR Founder Director</ref><ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/353953.cms Antarctica team to leave on Friday]. [[The Times of India]], 12 December 2003, Prem Chand Pandey Director NCAOR at the Time.</ref><ref>[http://www.frontlineonnet.com/fl2125/stories/20041217003609700.htm Mission Antarctica]. ''Frontline,'' December 04–17, 2004, Dr. P C Pandey Founder Director NCAOR</ref><ref>[http://www.hinduonnet.com/2005/01/07/stories/2005010704171200.htm Sagar Kanya begins Indian Ocean expedition to study tsunami impact]. ''The Hindu'', 7 January 2005, Dr. Prem Chand Pandey Founder Director NCAOR</ref><ref>[http://www.hinduonnet.com/fline/fl2022/stories/20031107003609900.htm Reaching the final frontier]. ''Frontline,'' 25 October–7 November 2003, Dr. Prem Chand Pandey Founding Director National Centre for Antarctic and Ocean Research(NCAOR)</ref><ref>[http://dod.nic.in/pressbrief.htm Shri Kapil Sibal, Honourable Minister of State (Independent Charge), S&T and Ocean Development visited Antarctica from 2nd to 4th of February 2005, the first ever visit by an Indian Minister] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717095920/http://dod.nic.in/pressbrief.htm |date=2011-07-17 }}. Dr. Prem Chand Pandey, the then Director, National Centre for Antarctic & Ocean Research(NCAOR) was one of the member of the delegation as on DOD Web Page.</ref> NCAOR is known for its participation in global experiments, hosting of international conferences and in the leadership of international committees concerned with Antarctic science. At present, NCAOR is an agency working under [[Ministry of Earth Sciences (India)|Ministry of Earth Sciences]], [[Government of India]] since 2006, by the notification of the President of India.
NCAOR complex is a home to a special low-temperature laboratory and is setting up a National Antarctic Data Centre and a Polar Museum.
The NCAOR operates in different fields or tasks:
* storing [[ice core]] samples, from Antarctica and the [[Himalayan Mountains]]. * operating the [[Himadri Station|Himadri]] Arctic research station in [[Spitsbergen]], [[Norway]].<ref>http://ncaor-arctic.ncaor.org:5050/website/index.html NCAOR Arctic Research</ref> * managing the oceanic research vessel ''[[ORV Sagar Kanya]]'', the flagship of India's fleet of [[oceanography|oceanographic]] study vessels. This ship has contributed significantly{{Vague|date=March 2008}}<!-- How? --> to India's study of the [[Arabian Sea]], the [[Bay of Bengal]], and the Indian Ocean. * it supported the [[KBCAOS]], [[University of Allahabad]] from initial stage of establishment up to the final stage of the center as full-fledged faculty centre, in form of a project as per collaborative work with the University.<ref name=NCAOR1 />
This centre was previously referred to as Antarctic Study Centre. It came into existence with joining of Dr [[Prem Chand Pandey]] as the director on 12 May 1997.<ref>[http://www.iitbbs.ac.in/faculty/iit_1338424939.pdf "came into existence with joining P C Pandey as Centre Director"]. (PDF) Antarctic Study Centre came in existence with Dr. Pandey</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ncaor.gov.in/ Official website]

[[Image:NCI logo.jpg|thumb|Logo of the NCI]] The '''Natural Capital Initiative''' (NCI) is a partnership of UK organisations which promotes and supports decision-making across government, business and the private sector that results in the sustainable management of our [[natural capital]].<ref name=CEH>{{cite web|title=The Natural Capital Initiative|url=https://www.ceh.ac.uk/natural-capital-initiative|website=www.ceh.ac.uk|publisher=Centre for Ecology & Hydrology|accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref> Formed in 2009, it is a partnership between two of the UK's learned societies and two of its scientific research institutes,<ref>{{cite web|title=Natural Capital Initiative|url=http://www.britishecologicalsociety.org/public-policy/natural-capital-initiative/|publisher=British Ecological Society|accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref> namely: *[[Centre for Ecology and Hydrology]] *[[Royal Society of Biology]] *[[British Ecological Society]] *[[James Hutton Institute]].
==Aims== Its stated mission is "to support decision-making that results in the sustainable management of our natural capital based on sound science".<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Mission|url=http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk/about/|website=www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk|publisher=National Capital Initiative|accessdate=6 March 2016}}</ref> It aims to provide decision-makers from UK government, academia, business, and civil society with a high-level forum for cross-sectoral dialogue on how to realise the UK government's stated objective of embedding [[natural capital]] thinking in policy and practice, and it does this based upon sound evidence from across the natural and social sciences.<ref name=CEH/>
The four main objectives of the Natural Capital Initiative are to:
*Inform the Government's implementation of the [[Ecosystem Approach|ecosystems approach]] - a framework for looking at whole ecosystems in decision-making and valuing the services they provide. *Identify gaps in science, policy and implementation that inhibit an ecosystems approach. *Work with government, parliament, agencies, [[NGO]]s, the private sector, scientific bodies and the wider public. *Inspire the next generation to engage in the sustainable use of the natural environment.
==History== [[File:Natural Capital graphic.jpg|thumb|[[Natural Capital]] provides us with essential functions and [[ecosystem services]].The NCI supports the UK government and policy-makers in putting natural capital at the heart of economic decision-making.]] The NCI was established in 2009 in response to the increasing global awareness of the need for more sustainable management of the world's limited natural resources,<ref name="education">{{cite web|title=Educating human capital for the preservation of natural capital|url=http://consciouscomms.com/educating-human-capital-for-the-preservation-of-natural-capital/|website=consciouscomms.com|publisher=Conscious Communications|accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref> as highlighted by the 2005 [[Millennium Ecosystem Assessment]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Overview of the Milliennium Ecosystem Assessment|url=http://millenniumassessment.org/en/About.html|website=millenniumassessment.org|publisher=Millennium Ecosystem Assessment|accessdate=6 March 2016}}</ref> It was launched in April 2009 at a three-day [[symposium]] held in London, entitled ''Valuing our Life Support Systems''. Its conclusions were published in August 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=Valuing Our Life Support Systems: Symposium Report|url=http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/nci_full_lo-2.pdf|website=www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk|accessdate=4 March 2016|date=1 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Valuing Our Life Support Systems: Symposium Report Executive Summary|url=http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/nci_summary_lo-2.pdf|website=www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk|publisher=Natural Capital Initiative|accessdate=4 March 2016|date=1 May 2009}}</ref><ref name=DEFRA>{{cite web|title=What nature can do for you|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/396840/pb13897-nature-do-for-you.pdf|website=www.gov.uk|publisher=DEFRA|accessdate=7 March 2016|page=23|date=January 2015}}</ref>
In 2012 the James Hutton Institute announced it was joining the partnership.<ref name=Hutton>{{cite web|title=James Hutton Institute joins the Natural Capital Initiative|url=http://www.hutton.ac.uk/news/james-hutton-institute-joins-natural-capital-initiative|website=www.hutton.ac.uk|accessdate=5 March 2016|date=17 October 2012}}</ref>
In November 2014 the NCI held a second major symposium/summit, entitled: ‘Valuing our Life Support Systems’ with the aim of pushing forward the shared natural capital agenda.<ref name=CEH/>
The Chair of the NCI (as at 2016) is Professor Alison Hester of the [[James Hutton Institute]]<ref>{{cite web|title=NCI Chair|url=http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk/secretariat/|website=www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref>
==Influence== The Natural Capital Initiative has been recognised as one of the key groups or organisations in the UK now examining the main issues surrounding the depletion of natural resources and in encouraging the preservation of natural capital.<ref name=Hutton/>
Its 2009 symposium recommendations are included in the UK government own recommendations and resource documents to senior policy-makers.<ref name=DEFRA/>
In recent years the NCI's support for the development of high-level policy based on sound science, and in line with an ecosystems approach to decision-making, has transferred into reality in a number of ways. In particular, the [[Natural Capital Committee]], supported by [[DEFRA]], evolved out of the UK Government's 2011 'Natural Environment White Paper', as did the 48 [[Local Nature Partnership]]s now established across England which focus on sustainable land management, greening economic growth and human health and wellbeing.<ref name=education/>
In 2014 the NCI called on the UK government to introduce a [[natural capital accounting]] element into its [[National accounts|national accounting framework]], and supported the Natural Capital Committee's own proposal for a 25-year Government plan for the UK Natural Environment, which is now under development.<ref>{{cite web|title=Natural Capital Initiative urges Government act now to reverse decline in natural capital|url=https://www.rsb.org.uk/news/14-news/1122-natural-capital-initiative-urges-government-to-act-now-to-reverse-decline-in-natural-capital|website=www.rsb.org.uk|publisher=Royal Society of Biology|accessdate=5 March 2016|date=28 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Government will produce a 25 year plan for the natural environment|url=http://esinternational.com/government-will-produce-a-25-year-plan-for-the-natural-environment/|website=esinternational.com|publisher=ESI|accessdate=6 March 2016|date=27 October 2014}}</ref>
In 2015 the NCI published a symposium report, entitled 'Valuing our Life Support Systems', which was launched at a [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|parliamentary]] event on 25 June.<ref>{{cite web|title=Valuing our Life Support Systems Report Launch|url=http://www.parliament.uk/mps-lords-and-offices/offices/bicameral/post/post-events/valuing-our-life-support-systems-report-launch-/|website=www.parliament.uk|publisher=UK Parliament|accessdate=6 March 2016|date=25 June 2015}}</ref> The launch was chaired by [[Barry Gardiner|Barry Gardiner MP]]. The report spelled out the need for a methodology to be established for valuing natural capital. It also raised concerns there was a danger that natural capital could be treated as a commodity unless an ethical framework was in place to ensure the process of natural capital valuation was applied fairly and evenly. It urged that all natural capital concepts needed to be clear, evidence-based and robust, and it welcomed the Government's proposal to extend the life of the Natural Capital Committee until at least the end of that current parliament.<ref>{{cite web|title=Natural Capital Initiative: Valuing our Life Support Systems Report|url=http://www.parliament.uk/documents/post/Valuingourlifesupportsystemssummaryfinal.pdf|website=www.parliament.uk|publisher=Houses of Parliament|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> {{Quote|I love this report...I shall steal shamelessly [from it]...I thought the phrase "''The UK is a world leader in environmental science and in writing policy; it is not a world leader in taking subsequent action''" was just gorgeous; it should be written in capital letters over the entrance of [[DEFRA]]!...There has been avoidable failure by government. If government had included natural capital in their decision-making processes right from the beginning it would not have failed in the way that it has to deliver all those things.|author=[[Barry Gardiner|Barry Gardiner MP]] 25 June 2015<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gardiner MP|first1=Barry|title=Valuing our Life Support Systems Report Launch: Chair’s welcome (mp3)|url=http://www.parliament.uk/audio/post/VoLSS/NatCapevent1.mp3|website=www.parliament.uk|accessdate=6 March 2016}}</ref>}}
==Publications== *[http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/nci_full_lo-2.pdf Valuing Our Life Support Systems, Symposium Report. 2009] *[http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/Valuing-our-Life-Support-Systems-summit-report.pdf Natural Capital Initiative 2015: Valuing our Life Support Systems 2014. Summit Summary Report] *[http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/nci_full_lo-2.pdf Valuing Our Life Support Systems, Symposium Report. 2009] *http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Natural-Capital-Initiative_Strategy_2014-2018.pdf Natural Capital Initiative Strategic Plan 2014–2018]
<ref>{{cite web|title=Natural Capital Initiative Strategic Plan 2014 – 2018 (Mid-term review 2016|url=http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Natural-Capital-Initiative_Strategy_2014-2018.pdf|website=www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org|publisher=NCI|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref>
== References == {{Commons category|Natural capital}} {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == *[http://www.naturalcapitalinitiative.org.uk The Natural Capital Initiative homepage] *[http://www.britishecologicalsociety.org/ British Ecological Society homepage] *[https://www.rsb.org.uk Royal Society of Biology] *[http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/policy/natural-environ/ecosystems/index.htm Defra Ecosystems Approach] *[http://www.hutton.ac.uk/ James Hutton Institute] *[http://uknea.unep-wcmc.org/Home/tabid/38/Default.aspx UK National Ecosystems Assessment] *[https://www.gov.uk/guidance/ecosystems-services Guidance for policy and decision makers on using an ecosystems approach and valuing ecosystem services] *
